Description: The Erb Institute Student Advisory Board supports the academic, social, and professional pursuits of Erb Institute MBA/MS students. SAB advises Erb Institute staff on student priorities and promotes student participation in Institute activities.
Summary: The Erb Institute Student Advisory Board supports the academic, social, and professional pursuits of Erb Institute MBA/MS students. SAB advises Erb Institute staff on student priorities and promotes student participation in Institute activities.

Name: Eta Kappa Nu
Description: Eta Kappa Nu (HKN) exists to recognize the academic achievements of students in the EECS department. In addition to simply having scholastic achievement, we value character and demonstrated commitment to the various communities of which we are a part. As such, members must participate in community service activities in order to successfully join. We also provide opportunities for socialization among our members, as well as with other societies, including TBP, SWE, and IEEE. We also represent the EECS student body to the EECS department and College of Engineering by participating in various committees and events. Corporate recruiters come to HKN to bring technical and recruiting talks to campus, both specifically for HKN members as well as for the whole EECS student body.
Summary: An honor society for students in the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department. We manage the dB Café in the EECS building, contribute to community service projects, and facilitate social and networking opportunities for our members.

Name: Eta Sigma Phi
Description: The Alpha Eta chapter of Eta Sigma Phi, the national Classics honors society, is dedicated to the promotion of interest in the classical world. Members participate in weekly meetings and events such as faculty talks, graduate student panels, game nights, museum visits and more.
Summary: The Alpha Eta chapter of Eta Sigma Phi, the national Classics honors society, is dedicated to the promotion of interest in the classical world.

Name: Euchre Club
Description: This club aims to bring together University of Michigan students through the game of Euchre. We provide a community for Euchre enthusiasts to get together and kick back. The Euchre Club plans to create university wide card tournaments and philanthropic events, and host social events.
Summary: This club brings together University of Michigan students through the game of Euchre. We provide a community for Euchre enthusiasts to get together and kick back.

Name: European Business Students Association
Description: The EBSA intends to increase interaction among Ross students interested in Europe through professional and social events. The club will assist students interested in internships or full-time careers in Europe, facilitate relations with Ross alumni in Europe as well as European Ross alumni across the globe, and serve as a resource for European students exploring career opportunities in the U.S. Additionally, the EBSA will promote the Ross School of Business to potential applicants from Europe. Finally, the club intends to educate members of the Ross community about the culture and traditions of different European countries.
Summary: The European Business Student Association provides opportunities for students of all backgrounds to involve themselves professionally and culturally with Europe.

Name: Evans Scholars
Description: The Chick Evans Caddie Scholarship is a full tuition and housing college scholarship for golf caddies that is renewable for up to four years. Each year, more than 1,000 deserving caddies across the country attend college on a full ride scholarship from the Evans Scholars Foundation. Selected applicants must have a strong caddie record, excellent grades, outstanding character and demonstrated financial need.
Summary: The Evans Scholars Foundation is a charitable trust that provides full, four-year tuition and housing college scholarships for deserving caddies. The Foundation is overseen by the Western Golf Association.

Name: Every Three Weekly/UAC
Description:
Styled after the prestigious humor newspaper "The Onion," the Every Three Weekly seeks to provide the University of Michigan campus with a biting, satirical look into hot news items, current pressing issues, and happenings on campus in a newspaper that is published about once per month.

If you would like to receive an application to join the Every Three Weekly, please email us at threeweeks@umich.edu.
Summary: The E3W Newspaper delivers a fresh batch of wit and cynicism to the campus, you guessed it, every three weeks.

Name: Exposure Productions
Description:
Here at Exposure Productions, our mission is to produce pro-shot films of live productions for students and professionals, and to create promotional material for these local artists so they may create a wide and accessible audience on the internet. We want to provide our local theater makers, musicians, dancers, and artists a streamlined and concise process of creating personalized video content. These videos may include recruitment videos, teasers, series, social media videos, and full-length pro-shot performances. Exposure Productions also aims to give up and coming filmmakers professional experience before entering the industry.

Joining our organization means you'll help produce, film, and edit these videos while collaborating with local artists to make something special. For more information about getting a pro-shot scheduled or to join the organization, please navigate to our website.
Summary: Exposure Productions is a student-run production company specializing in filming live performances.

Name: Fall Engineering Career Fair
Description: The purpose of this organization is to bring companies to the University of Michigan to enable engineering students to get careers in industry, provide a revenue source for the Society of Women Engineers and Tau Beta Pi, and provide the opportunity for student members to show their leadership and organizational skills while maintaining and building relations with corporate representatives.
Summary: The purpose of the SWE/TBP Career Fair is to bring companies to the University of Michigan to enable students to obtain careers in industry. We are one of the largest student-run career fairs in the nation.

Name: FATE
Description:
Are you looking for a volunteer opportunity that engages youth in Detroit? If so, Give Merit’s mentorship program, FATE, is looking for University of Michigan students to become mentors!  

 

WHO WE ARE 

Our student organization, “FATE”, is a collection of students who recruit and participate as mentors for the FATE program (facilitated by a non-profit organization called Give Merit) located in Detroit. Give Merit exists to enhance and extend educational opportunities to Detroit youth through innovative enrichment and mentorship activities. Since 2012, Give Merit has worked intensively with Detroit high school students through its FATE program.

 

THE FATE PROGRAM 

FATE is a four-year, cohort-based program for high school students in Detroit who attend the Jalen Rose Leadership Academy. Its mission is to provide resources and opportunities for Detroit youth to embrace education and become world-class citizens, with a goal to motivate each student to graduate high school and attend college.

 

CURRICULUM

The four-year curriculum features four capstone projects which include creating a marketing / advertising campaign, designing their own Merit product collection, planning and executing a city-wide charity event in Detroit - check out this video about "FATE In Our Stars" (video), and participating in rotational internships as a youth-driven marketing firm. The curriculum is complemented by ongoing soft-skill building activities and regular excursion workshops where students are exposed to a variety of local / national organizations such as Zingerman’s, Google, Carhartt, and Plante Moran.

 

BEING A MENTOR

As mentors, we are paired with 1-2 mentees for the entire year which offers a lot of opportunities for relationship building. The purpose of the mentorship component of the FATE program is to provide guidance and support to our mentees throughout the year. We help facilitate workshop activities where students learn skills in business, marketing, and design thinking while also supporting our mentees as they develop personally and academically. We do our best to demystify the college experience by talking to them about our majors, our extracurricular activities, and what we hope to do after graduation. 

 

JOIN US!

We are looking for students who are interested in making an impact in their community and investing in the lives of youth by becoming a mentor! Mentors will be assigned to one cohort (9th - 12th grade) and will attend programming on a weekly basis in Detroit! Transportation can be provided if needed. 

 

Check out this video to learn more about the FATE Program (video) and this video to learn more about the mentor experience! (video) 

 

For more details about mentorship, please contact FATE’s Program Success Director, Rachel Mazzaro, at rmazzaro@meritgoodness.com
Summary: Join us in mentoring Detroit youth through the FATE Program! FATE provides resources and opportunities for Detroit youth to embrace education and become world-class citizens, with a goal to motivate each student to graduate high school and attend college

Name: FeelGood at the University of Michigan
Description:
FeelGood is a volunteer youth movement committed to ending global hunger in our lifetime.

We raise money for the end of hunger by running FeelGood Grilled Cheese Delis on our campus and creating care packages. Every penny we raise—100%—is invested in hunger-ending organizations with a proven track record of success.

Our goal is to support The Hunger Project and also establish a community of motivated altruists. We use our delis as a point of dialogue to increase awareness of global hunger and the hunger-ending strategies that really work.
Summary: FeelGood's mission is to reach the sustainable end of world hunger - one grilled cheese at a time.

Name: Felicity Foundation
Description:
The purpose of this orgization is to serve Allah by connecting people to their Lord and the Prophetic Legacy by facilitating a vibrant service-oriented campus community.

The orgaization will focus on four catagories to accomplish this goal.

Outreach to undergraduate students, graduate students, and the greater Muslim Community. 

Spiritual Grounding through knowledge and worship.

Community Development by consistant events and interactions between people of diverse backgrounds.

Student Services through access to knowlegde and platforms to build resources.
Summary:
Connecting people to their Lord and the Prophetic Legacy by facilitating a vibrant
service-oriented campus community.
Its scope is under the following four categories:
Outreach, Spiritual Grounding, Student Services, Community Development

Name: Filipino American Student Association
Description:
The Filipino American Student Association thrives on Filipino and Filipino American culture as the driving force behind its continuing efforts to educate others about the Filipino heritage.

 

CULTURE

To effectively and accurately communicate, cultivate, and exemplify Filipino culture and Filipinx/Filipinx American identities.

 

COMMUNITY

To foster an inclusive and welcoming space for all.

 

OUTREACH

To serve and connect with the University of Michigan, the Midwest, and the Philippines while expressing solidarity and engaging in advocacy with other organizations and marginalized communities.

 

Interested in becoming a member? Fill out this form!

Click here for the official website.
Summary: The Filipino American Student Association thrives on Filipino and Filipino American culture as the driving force behind its continuing efforts to educate others about the Filipino heritage.

Name: Film and Video Student Association
Description: Film and Video Student Association endeavors to enrich the educational and social atmosphere of the Film Television and Media department at the University of Michigan. By bringing together a multitude of talents in the pursuit of organizing workshops, movie nights, contests, field trips, networking with industry professionals, and other various activities, we seek to be a dynamic organization that is academically active and socially responsive.
Summary: FVSA aims to bring together students who love to watch and make movies. We hold screenings, social events, and career events. Lightworks, a student film festival at the end of the Fall and Winter semesters, is our biggest event.

Name: Filmic Productions
Description:
Back in 2010, a group of U-M students got together with a single goal: to tell the highest quality stories through video on the Michigan campus. Their majors were diverse, ranging from business to pharmacy to, of course, Screen Arts & Cultures (now FTVM). While their specific skill sets varied, they were collectively passionate about the moving image, and discovered that by working together they could make better films than each could alone. They called their collaboration “Filmic.”

Soon after its founding, Filmic was presented with the opportunity to start telling stories about Michigan, working with administrators across the University – in Student Life, Development, Athletics, and Admissions to name just a few – to chronicle the student experience through film. And thus, Filmic became U-M’s first student-led creative production company. We specialize in creative storytelling and are dedicated to developing unique ideas that stand out among typical commercial videos; from pre- to post-production we take a vision from concept to reality, while engaging diverse perspectives and embracing our motto of cinema everywhere. Filmic Productions has had the opportunity to work with notable clients including Lady Gaga’s Born This Way Foundation, The Michigan Dance Building, and OTZI Skin, a California-based cosmetics company.

Filmic’s core credo – “Cinema Everywhere” – stems from a collective belief that any story can be made cinematic and impactful, and its members bring that energy to every project they take on.

If you're interested in joining Filmic, our application is due on September 12th 2023 by 11:59pm! We are looking for Art Directors, Directors of Photography, Writers, Editors, Sound Engineers, and Producers! Further information can be found on our website or instagram.

Please email us with any questions.
Summary:
Cinema Everywhere.

Filmic Productions is a student-run, creative production agency, dedicated to producing the highest quality content for clients at The University of Michigan and beyond.

Name: FIRST Alumni and Mentors Network at Michigan
Description:
FAMNM is an on campus effort to unite all of the various departmental and individual student efforts that support FIRST® programs locally and throughout the state of Michigan. FAMNM supports FIRST teams with funds, mentors, volunteers, resources, and publicity, works to strengthen the relationship between the University of Michigan and FIRST programs, and supports robotics-focused STEM engagement efforts throughout the state.

FAMNM is a collegiate network for FIRST alumni and supporters. From mass-mentoring opportunities like Ri3D, opportunities to build personal connections with our corporate sponsors, and volunteer travel reimbursements FAMNM works to engage FIRST alumni and supporters from all backgrounds and levels of involvement. FAMNM provides professional development opportunities including leadership opportunities, resume critiquing, and corporate recruiting events.

More information and ways to get involved can be found at our website: famnm.club
Summary: The mission of FAMNM is to inspire K-12 students to pursue STEM, business, & community outreach opportunities; to support Michigan FIRST teams, mentors, & volunteers; and to develop a professional network of FIRST supporters at the University of Michigan

Name: First at Ross
Description:
Purpose: First at Ross is established to advance the community, awareness, and advocacy of first-generation college graduate students, staff, and members of the Ross School of Business and the broader professional business world. In addition, we promote allyship for this community by educating their fellow faculty, staff, and MBA peers about the challenges - in the classroom and the boardroom. 

Mission: Through campus involvement, our mission is to increase Ross community awareness of student/staff/faculty/business professionals that identify as first-generation college graduates through thoughtful programming, education, and events.
Summary: First at Ross is a affinity group that advances the community, awareness, and advocacy of first-generation college graduate students, staff, and members of Ross School of Business and the broader professional business world.

Name: First Generation Law Students
Description:
First Generation Law Students (FGLS) is focused on supporting first-generation college students and low income students at MLaw. First, we want to prepare first-generation law students for entering the legal profession. We do this by offering programming on networking, interviewing, and career planning. Second, we aim to create a supportive environment for first-generation law students. We create this space by organizing panels on grades, journals, and other academic topics, by hosting discussions on issues affecting first-generation students, and by maintaining a mentoring program comprised of 2Ls and 3Ls.

https://www.firstgenmlaw.com
Summary: First Generation Law Students (FGLS) is focused on supporting first-generation college students and low income students at MLaw.

Name: First Year Experience
Description:
First Year Experience (FYE) is an office that creates a welcoming community for students in their transition to campus by engaging them in programs related to personal and academic growth, navigating campus resources, building meaningful connections with others, and prioritizing well-being.

 

We offer programs on skill development and information sharing, including Time Management, Prioritize Wellness, Money Management, and more. These programs are peer facilitated - you can check out our website for a calendar of events and request our programs at a date and time that work for you.

 

We also offer programs on community building through Community Meet Ups and the Community Matters Cohort Program! Find the Meet Ups calendar on our website as well.
Summary: First Year Experience (FYE) is an office that creates a welcoming community for students in their transition to campus.

Name: First Year Information Program
Description: The First Year Information Program (FYI) helps new students adjust to life as a Michigan Law student. Upper-class FYI Leaders plan and host programs of interest for first-year students, including panel discussions on exam preparation, journals, and class registration. Through these events, FYI aims to prepare first-year students for law school and a career in the legal profession, to connect them to resources in the greater University of Michigan community, and to build collegiality and community.
Summary: Peer-advising program for first-year law students.

Name: First-Generation College Students @ Michigan
Description: In the Fall of 2007, with great assistance from UM Administration and Residence Education, a small team of undergraduate and graduate students created a program that hopes to eventually offer a variety of resources, advising, and outreach to current and future first generation university students and their parents. First-Generation College Students @ Michigan is a newly formed student organization dedicated to the goals of recognizing, raising awareness of, and resolving the unique needs of first generation college students at the University of Michigan. We are proud to announce that First-Generation College Students @ Michigan is the first student-lead organization of its type in the nation.
Summary: First-Generation College Students @ Michigan is a student organization dedicated to recognizing, raising awareness of, and resolving the needs of undergraduate first-generation college students on the University of Michigan's campus.

Name: First-Generation Pre-Health Association
Description: FGPA was established to provide additional support and guidance to those who identify as first-generation college students and intend to pursue a career in healthcare. The FGPA helps its members navigate the often overlooked challenges and circumstances that pre-health first-gen college students often encounter. By sharing resources, developing leadership skills, and establishing mentorship opportunities we aim to facilitate first-generation students’ preparation for future careers in healthcare.
Summary: By sharing resources, developing leadership skills, and establishing mentorship opportunities we aim to facilitate first-generation students’ preparation for future careers in the healthcare industry.

Name: Fleece & Thank You
Description: Fleece and Thank You at the University of Michigan is a student organization affiliated with the non-profit Fleece & Thank You. The mission of Fleece & Thank You is to provide comfort and hope to children admitted to Michigan hospitals, by giving them a fleece blanket that comes with a personalized video message. As a student organization on campus, our purpose is to facilitate the connection between Fleece & Thank You and our community, give volunteers the unique opportunity to fundraise or participate in activities that further the mission of Fleece and Thank You, and to work amongst other student organizations or volunteers who are interested in hosting a blanket-making event on the University of Michigan's campus.
Summary: Fleece and Thank You at the University of Michigan is a student organization affiliated with the non-profit Fleece & Thank You.

Name: Fletcher Organized Residents Celebrating Everyone
Description: FORCE is an opportunity for Fletcher residents to promote an environment of cultural and social awareness through activities and events which aim to unify all members of the Fletcher Hall Community. FORCE is the governing body of Fletcher Hall.
Summary: The purpose of this organization is to serve as the governing body of Fletcher Hall, as well as to promote an environment of cultural and social awareness through activities and events which aim to unify all members of Fletcher Hall community.

Name: Flowdom
Description: Established in 2015, Flowdom is a co-ed Hip Hop dance group that is open to different genres of music and styles of dance. We aim to put on entertaining choreographed performances, whilst incorporating freestyle dancing in order to develop unique style and flow. All the while, we make a legitimate effort to socialize outside of our scheduled sessions to collectively evolve as a group.
Summary: Flowdom is a co-ed Hip Hop dance group open to various styles of music and dance. We perform self-choreographed routines that incorporate freestyle at events on campus. The Flowdom Family creates strong bonds through a common passion for dance.

Name: Flywheel - Women's Ultimate Frisbee
Description: We are the University of Michigan's Women's Ultimate Frisbee team. Recognized by the university as a Club Sport, we travel across the country to compete against other high-level programs. Flywheel is made up of many different members, from freshmen who picked up their first disc at tryouts to grad students who have been playing for years. For seven of the past ten years, we have qualified for Nationals, most recently placing 2nd in 2011, 3rd in 2012, 5th in 2014, and 9th in 2016, 2017, and 2018, and 19th in 2021.
Summary: Women's Ultimate Frisbee

Name: Follies at Ross
Description: The mission of Follies is to provide students interested in comedy writing, stage performance, directing, choreography, improv, stand-up, and digital content creation a chance to learn and experiment, satirically at Ross
Summary: The mission of Follies is to provide students interested in comedy writing, stage performance, directing, choreography, improv, stand-up, and digital content creation a chance to learn and experiment, satirically at Ross

Name: Food Recovery Network at University of Michigan
Description: The Food Recovery Network at the University of Michigan is an organization dedicated to fighting food waste, food insecurity, and hunger in the Ann Arbor region. To do so, students recover surplus food from campus dining halls and local farms and donates it to the food bank Food Gatherers and the university food pantry Maize & Blue Cupboard. FRN is also committed to raising awareness about the issues of community hunger and food waste through hands-on opportunities and educational outreach. The Food Recovery Network at the University of Michigan is part of an extensive network of FRN chapters that exist at a number of college campuses nationwide.
Summary: The Food Recovery Network at the University of Michigan fights food waste and hunger in the Ann Arbor community by recovering surplus food from University of Michigan dining halls and nearby farms and donating it to local food banks.

Name: Food, Bev, and Ag Club at Michigan Ross
Description: The Food, Bev, and Ag (FB&A) club exists to serve the MBA students of the Ross School of Business by creating a community for students who are interested in exploring career opportunities in the food, beverage, and agriculture industries.
Summary: The Food, Bev, and Ag ("FB&A") club exists to serve the MBA students of the Ross School of Business by creating a community for students who are interested in exploring career opportunities in the food, beverage, and agriculture industries.

Name: Ford + Munk Conference Committee
Description:
The Ford+Munk Conference is an annual student-led policy conference among students at the University of Toronto Munk School of Global Affairs & Public Policy and the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy (the Ford School), one of America’s premier public policy institutions. Held in the Winter/Spring (Ford/Munk) semester, the event brings together students from both schools in a team-based learning environment where they are challenged to analyze, evaluate, and present key findings related to a current policy issue facing both sides of the border. It’s a great opportunity to further your understanding of multi-stakeholder and cross-border policy collaboration and implementation – and have fun in the process!   At the conclusion of the weekend, a panel of faculty judges will select the best proposal.

Organized as a case competition, Ford+Munk aims to achieve the following objectives:

  • Develops a policy student’s problem solving capabilities through a vehicle that is uncommon in policy programs;
  • Allows for Ford and Munk students to interact in a more intimate setting;
  • Acts as an exercise rooted in developing teamwork and presentation skills;

Students are placed into case teams ahead of time, and each team will feature a mix of Ford and Munk students.  No preparation is necessary leading up to the conferences.
Summary: This committee is run by graduate students from the Ford School of Public Policy and the University of Toronto's Munk School of Public Policy and Governance. We hold an annual case competition with participants from both schools.

Name: Ford School Student Affairs Committee
Description: SAC is the liaison between Ford School graduate students, faculty, and staff.  Its members are chosen in biannual elections from the graduate student body.  We represent graduate student interests to the administration, and we disburse administration funds set aside for graduate student organization activities.  We are also responsible for graduate student engagement, host the Ford School Town Halls, as well as several other programs.
Summary: The Student Affairs Committee serves and advocates for the student community of the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy. We work to build community, create transparency, and respond to the needs of students.

Name: Ford School Undergraduate Council
Description: UGC is the Ford School student government. We act as a conduit between the administration and undergraduate students, and work to ensure that Ford undergrads have a great experience. To this end, we facilitate social, philanthropic, and other events for Ford students.
Summary: The primary purpose of this organization is to serve the undergraduate student body of the Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy.

Name: Forensic/Speech Team
Description:
The Forensic/Speech Team was established to build a community of public speakers. Our team hosts high school speech tournaments and travels to various colleges to compete in dramatic interpretation, public address, and debate events.

Our general meetings are on Fridays from 9:00 PM to 11:00 PM. Times are subject to changes.

Visit our website for any updates and join our Discord to stay connected:

Website: https://osarius.github.io/Forensics/

Discord: https://discord.com/invite/SuEgRmjTT8
Summary: The Forensic/Speech Team is established to build a community of public speakers. Our team hosts high school speech tournaments and travels to various colleges to compete in dramatic interpretation, public address, and debate events.

Name: Foundation for International Medical Relief of Children
Description: The Foundation for International Medical Relief of Children (FIMRC) is a national non-profit organization whose mission is to provide access to medical care for underprivileged and medically underserved children and families around the world. Our chapter contributes to this mission by adopting fundraising projects at our many clinics abroad, while also advocating for and informing our members on relevant global health issues. We also offer the opportunity for service-learning trips at our clinics abroad, during which members gain insights into health care systems in other countries as well as make a difference within the local communities the clinics serve. At home, we fundraise for our clinical projects through events such as our Benefit Dinner, Mr. Michigan Pageant and raffles. FIMRC is also dedicated to making a difference within the Ann Arbor community through participation in local volunteering events. We are a tight-knit family of like-minded students interested in global health.
Summary: Our mission is to provide access to healthcare for low-resource and medically underserved families around the world.

Name: Fraker Conference Planning Committee
Description: The Fraker Conference Organizing Committee is made up of a group of graduate students in the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures. We organize, promote and participate in the Charles F. Fraker Conference, which hosts students from academic communities across the country as well as a selected keynote speaker.
Summary: Graduate student group in the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures charged with the organization and promotion of the Charles F. Fraker Graduate Student Conference.

Name: French Speakers Association at The University of Michigan
Description: FSA is a student association for students at the University of Michigan from French-speaking countries all around the world. We founded this club in the hopes of connecting native and heritage speakers of French on campus. Our association is a cultural and social club rather than an educational club. For students learning French, FSA strongly recommends looking into the other amazing French clubs that UM has to offer!
Summary: FSA is a student association for students at the University of Michigan from French-speaking countries all around the world. We founded this club in the hopes of connecting native and heritage speakers of French on campus.

Name: Fridays for Future at the University of Michigan
Summary: We are the University of Michigan chapter of the international, decentralized Friday's for Future movement that advocates for nonviolent direct action as a method of mitigating the climate crisis.

Name: Friends for St. Jude at UMich
Description: St. Jude Children's Research Hospital is a non-profit that gets around 80% of its funds from donors, and uses those funds to pay for ALL patient's cancer treatments as well as the research that goes toward helping find cures. Since the hospital was founded a little over 50 years ago, the childhood cancer survival rate has gone from 20% to nearly 80%. Friends for St. Jude supports St. Jude Children's Research Hospital as they improve means of prevention and cures for pediatric cancer. We host an annual No More Cancer Rally and other fundraisers, to help pay for patients' treatments and advance research. We hope to develop your leadership and networking skills as we raise funds for the children of St. Jude, and ultimately, all the children who suffer from pediatric cancer.
Summary: We support St. Jude Children's Research Hospital as they improve means of prevention and research cures for pediatric cancer. We primarily host fundraisers to help pay for patient's treatments and advance research.

Name: Friends of Guatemala
Description:
Friends of Guatemala is a volunteer organization founded in 2023 at the University of Michigan with the goal of helping the students of Guatemala’s Ak’ Tenamit school system, specifically in the Q’eqchi' Mayan village Seacacar, but also in other parts of eastern Guatemala. Through raising money for donations, gathering educational supplies such as books and technology, and establishing a tutoring relationship between UMich students and Ak’ Tenamit students, we aim to improve access to education for those who have historically been subjugated and oppressed. 

 

FOG provides members the opportunity to participate in international community service and take part in building important relationships with students abroad through fundraising and/or weekly tutoring sessions. Members are not required to be tutors, and members are not required to know Spanish or Q’eqchi'. If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out!
Summary: Friends of Guatemala is a volunteer charity and tutoring organization focused on supporting the village of Seacacar in Guatemala. We raise donations and gather resources to support the village's school system and connect volunteer tutors to its students.

Name: Friends of the Gaffield Children's Garden
Description: The Gaffield Children’s Garden new sponsored student organization, Friends of the Gaffield Children’s Garden (FGCG), is welcome to all UM students interested in examining the intersection of Nature access and childhood outdoor play, furthering essential social justice efforts of diversity and inclusion within the UM community. Students involved in FGCG will shape the new sponsored student organization, develop leadership skills, participate in stewardship of GCG located at Matthaei Botanical Gardens, and collaborate with community partners. Students will also develop a critical lens on the important and tangible positive health and learning impacts nature access and childhood outdoor play provide.
Summary: FGCG invites ALL UM students interested in examining the intersection of Nature access and childhood outdoor play, furthering essential social justice efforts of diversity and inclusion within the UM community.

Name: Friends of the Gargoyle
Description: We sponsor making people laugh. A lot.
Summary: We bring humor and joy to the university through our dedication to the Gargoyle.

Name: FunKtion
Description:
Since its inaugural performance at Festifall, 1999, FunKtion has been dedicated to bringing its talent and energy to the University of Michigan campus and beyond.

 

When the initial ten members of FunKtion first combined their forces like Voltron, they had a vision of a multi-cultural group that would bring family-style fun to the masses. Proving that "guys have rhythm" was not the hardest part however. It was the late nights (practicing at Angell Hall, the Diag, the CCRB, or anywhere with some space and an electrical outlet) and the early mornings squeezed in-between the crush of academic and social commitments that truly showed us the importance of dance and brotherhood. All the hard work paid off each and every year, as FunKtion quickly grew into a recognizable entity.

 

FunKtion has been invited to perform at various events such as Festifall, A Taste of Culture, Encompass, Dance Marathon, Michigan Homecoming, Greek Week, KSA, Sixth Day, Celebrasia, Noir Fashion Show, Pioneer High School, 58 Greene concerts, Dance Mix, and a Detroit Pistons game. In its short history, FunKtion has traveled from the Midwest (UIUC, GVSU, Northwestern, opening for Jocelyn Enriquez) to the East Coast (Columbia for ECASU), opening for JCole. and it only gets bigger as FunKtion continually works to expand its repertoire and its presence.

 

The FunKtion family is reaching towards you with open arms and shuffling feet. Come support us wherever the bass reverberates and the boys dance.


We dance. You scream. FunKtion on three...
Summary: We are FunKtion, University of Michigan's first all-male, multicultural, hip-hop dance group. Founded on the principles of brotherhood, dance, and entertainment, we promote the joy and the welfare of the University's diverse community.

Name: Fusion Dance
Description: Fusion Dance is a dance club dedicated to providing all styles of dance for all levels of dancers. The goal is to promote inclusion by holding classes of different dance styles to allow dancers to grow.
Summary: Fusion Dance is a dance club dedicated to providing all styles of dance for all levels of dancers. The goal is to promote inclusion by holding classes of different dance styles to allow dancers to grow.

Name: Futsal Club at the University of Michigan
Description: Futsal Club at the University of Michigan is a place for futsal and soccer fanatics to bond over the beautiful game. Currently, there are several factors limiting Michigan students from pursuing these sports such as lack of fields, distance, weather, and unorganized pickup games. Together, we will resolve these issues by establishing an environment for friendly competition and exercise. We are open to anyone across campus who wants to engage in team building and make connections with fellow Wolverines.
Summary: Futsal Club at the University of Michigan is a place for futsal and soccer fanatics to bond over the beautiful game through friendly scrimmages and pickup matches with fellow Wolverines.

Name: Futures in Research, Science, Teaching
Description: The mission of FIRST is to prepare undergraduate students for the graduate school application process, the transition to research at the graduate level, and future pursuit of PhD-based careers. FIRST will connect undergraduates with graduate student mentors and hold events on science-based professional development, in addition to informing them about career paths within the biomedical sciences.
Summary: The mission of FIRST is to prepare undergraduate students for the graduate school application process, the transition to research at the graduate level, and future pursuit of PhD-based careers.

Name: Futuros Abogados
Description: We are committed to providing opportunities for law students to practice Spanish in a legal context, with the understanding that a better ability to communicate will make us better advocates. We seek to do so by holding regular Spanish language meetups, hosting Spanish-speaking attorneys for talks about practicing with Spanish-speaking clients, and through regular social events centering on Spanish-language media and discussion.
Summary: A platform for law students to practice Spanish in a legal context.

Name: Galens Medical Society
Description:
Galens Medical Society, founded in 1914, is the largest and oldest student group at the University of Michigan Medical School, and is comprised of about 120 medical students and 13 faculty Honoraries. The organization raises >$80,000 in its annual Tag Days fundraiser, and distributes this money to organizations within Mott hospital and to charities that benefit the children of Washtenaw County. Galens members take an active role in volunteerism, and interact socially with faculty through activities such as the Smoker, Welcome BBQ, tailgate, and the year-end banquet. The Galens Loan Fund helps defray the cost of residency interviewing at subsidized interest rates. Additionally, students continue to recognize and award teaching and leadership excellence among Medical School basic science and clinical faculty, as well as house officers.

The traditions of community service, extracurricular socialization, faculty cooperation and recognition, and student advocacy have remained central objectives throughout the organization's long history. The success and duration of the organization is attributable not only to the commitment, passion, and charity of its students, but also to that of its alumni and honorary faculty members, who over the years have dutifully served as advisors, mentors, and advocates.
Summary: Galens Medical Society, founded in 1914, is the largest and oldest student group at the University of Michigan Medical School, and is comprised of about 120 medical students and 13 faculty Honoraries.

Name: Galens Medical Society Smoker
Description: Galens Medical Society Smoker is a medical student organization at UM which produces the annual musical comedy "roast" of the medical school faculty, also known as "The Galens Smoker" or "The Smoker."
Summary: Galens Medical Society Smoker is a medical student organization at UM which produces the annual musical comedy "roast" of the medical school faculty, also known as "The Galens Smoker" or "The Smoker."

Name: Gamma Phi Beta
Description: Gamma Phi Beta is an international sorority established to promote the highest type of womanhood through education, social life, and service to country and humanity. Gamma Phi Beta is more than 140 years old and has been dedicated to continuing the vision of our Founders since day one. Members of the Sorority are wholeheartedly invested in our sisterhood and believe deeply in our philanthropic mission, vision and focus. There is a quiet strength that is evident across the sisters and a desire to remain true and constant to the Sorority, the friendships, the opportunities and the values.
Summary: We build confident women of character who celebrate sisterhood and make a difference in the world around us.

Name: Gear Up for Good
Description:
Our club is an organization that collects new or gently used sports equipment and donates it to individuals, teams, schools, and communities that are in need. The mission of the organization is to provide access to sports equipment and promote physical activity for youths and families.
The club typically accepts donations of various types of sports equipment, which is then sorted, cleaned, and distributed to those in need, based on the requests and needs of the recipients.
In addition to collecting and distributing equipment, Gear Up for Good may also hold events and programs to promote physical activity and provide educational resources on the benefits of sports and healthy living.
By collecting and donating sports equipment, our club is making a positive impact on the lives of individuals and families who may not have access to these resources. It helps to level the playing field and provides opportunities for everyone to participate in sports and physical activities, regardless of their economic status.
Summary: Our club is an organization that collects new or gently used sports equipment and donates it to individuals, teams, schools, and communities that are in need.

Name: Gender Diversity in Robotics
Description:
GENDiR strives to establish community and provide resources for students in Robotics whose experiences have been impacted by gender identity and/or expression. As part of this mission, we aim to:

  1. Foster an environment in which all members have a voice. 
  2. Organize events that promote social interaction and a feeling of camaraderie.
  3. Support the professional and academic development of all members.
Summary: GENDiR strives to establish community and provide resources for students in Robotics whose experiences have been impacted by gender identity and/or expression.

Name: Gender Minorities in Aerospace
Description: The organization of GeMA builds community, provides support, and facilitates opportunities for gender minorities in aerospace engineering at the University of Michigan with a focus on the experiences of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.
Summary: GeMA is a community for graduate and postdoc gender minorities in aerospace engineering.

Name: Gender Violence Project
Description:
GVP believes that every person has the right to feel safe and free from violence in their homes, communities, and workplaces. These rights are violated every day in a world where gender-based violence and sexual exploitation are common and commonly-accepted occurrences. We seek to remedy this violation by supporting women, trans people, and femme individuals at the Law School, while working to eradicate gender-based violence on our campus, in our community, and around the world.

 

Advocacy
GVP creates immediate opportunities for law students concerned about gender-based violence to take action at the law school, University of Michigan, and within the wider local community.

 

Education
GVP promotes awareness and provides resources regarding the intersection of sexual violence and the law in relation to the Michigan Law community. We work to destigmatize survivors of domestic violence, sexual assault and harassment, and gender discrimination through Educational events and feminist jurisprudence. We are committed to coordinating with student groups, professors, and Administrators at the Law School to create a community where everyone may productively discuss these topics.

 

We coordinate with the Dean of Academics and Dean of Student Life, as well as individual professors, when necessary, to assure feminist values are acknowledged and supported in the Law School. 

 

Careers
GVP advocates for students who are pursuing legal jobs that involve gender-based violence issues. We connect students with job listservs, alumni in relevant careers, connect with the Office of Career Planning (OCP) and Office of Alumni Relations for targeted support of GVP members’ needs. We also advocate for law students who may be experiencing gender-based harm and sexual harassment in the law school, at employer recruitment events, or in their legal internships. We work with OCP to assure transparent and effective reporting mechanisms are accessible to all law students.

 

Support
GVP seeks to create nonjudgmental spaces for people in the law school who don’t have a place to express themselves, unwind, and take a break. We welcome feminist viewpoints, critical analysis of the status quo, silence and reflection, and supportive socializing.
Summary: Gender Violence Project is a Michigan Law student organization dedicated to advocating for victims of gender-based violence.

Name: General Management Club
Description:
The General Management club caters to students interested in pursuing career paths that are cross-functional in nature and that typically lead to general management positions. The club's focus is on entry points for general management internships and positions immediately after business school, rather than on the future general management positions. This typically includes but is not limited to leadership rotational programs that provide for an accelerated career growth in an organization. Additionally, we also focus on Internal Strategy and Business Development roles.

The mission of the General Management Club is two-fold. First, the club fosters interaction between Ross MBAs and companies that are seeking talented students; secondly, the club prepares its members for recruitment through educational and networking events.

 

Visit us at CampusGroups for more details.
Summary: The General Management Club focuses on providing its members with leadership skills, well-rounded management expertise, and critical business perspectives to launch a career in corporate leadership.

Name: Generate Real Opportunities and Wonder Tutoring Program
Description: "The more you know, the more you grow!" Since 2014, G.R.O.W., a non-profit, has been dedicated to expanding opportunities and resources in STEM for urban elementary students while also improving literacy skills with an emphasis on hands-on learning.
Summary: "The more you know, the more you grow!" Since 2014, G.R.O.W., a non-profit, has been dedicated to expanding opportunities and resources in STEM for urban elementary students while also improving literacy skills with an emphasis on hands-on learning.

Name: Generation Asian Pacific American
Description: GenAPA is dedicated to hosting the largest Asian American culture show in the University of Michigan. We strive for community awareness, community service, and promoting Asian American culture. On an annual basis, GenAPA will host our show at the end of the Winter semester, showcasing the talents and culture of Asian Americans in the community, while advocating social justice and educating the community.
Summary: An Asian American organization devoted to hosting the largest Asian American culture show in the University of Michigan and promoting social justice and awareness throughout the community

Name: Generation Mental Heath - University of Michigan Campus Chapter
Description: Through campus involvement, our mission is to build future leaders for the mental health field out of members of the University of Michigan community.
Summary: Through campus involvement, our mission is to build future leaders for the mental health field out of members of the University of Michigan community.

Name: Genes in Diseases and Symptoms
Description: The University of Michigan chapter of GIDAS’s mission is to advocate genetic research for diseases through high school outreach and our own research! GIDAS engages in biology-focused educational programs in local high schools, some of which include teaching wet-lab techniques and computational biology/programming concepts. GIDAS members have the opportunity to learn computational biology skills from their peers and provide mentorship to high school students through the miRcore Volunteer Program. We also invite guest speakers involved in the computational biology and genetics fields to expose undergraduates to research and interdisciplinary career pathways in healthcare.
Summary: The University of Michigan chapter of GIDAS’s mission is to advocate genetic research for diseases through high school outreach and our own research activities.

Name: GeoClub
Description:
GeoClub is committed to providing graduate students and undergraduates a way to network both socially and professionally within the Earth science community at the University of Michigan and within the Earth science community at large,

   To developing field and technical skills tailored to the subject of Earth science that would otherwise not be learned in a classroom,

   To providing regional field trips for students, so that they may be able to experience a variety of settings that are not easily accessible due to the homogeneous, flat land of the lower peninsula of Michigan, 

   To keeping current students updated on the work of graduates and undergraduates with presentations of ongoing and past research, field experiences, and internships,   

   To participating in outreach programs that promote interest in Earth science,

   And lastly to providing career development and networking opportunities as well as resources to help students prepare for life after graduation.  

 

Homepage: https://sites.google.com/umich.edu/umgeoclub/home
Summary: GeoClub is a student organization for undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Michigan who are interested in Earth science.

Name: Geography Club
Description: Geography club will be a club that will promote and celebrate geography with an emphasis on human geography. Personally, we have found that geography education at the University of Michigan is slightly lacking, with no department, geography central classes offered, or geography clubs. We want to fill that gap by creating a space that educates and celebrates geography. This club will consist of geography games, education on different countries, human geography, and other global topics. Emphasizing spatial relationships between human communities, cultures, economies, and environmental interactions. Club meetings will be both fun and educational as well as held on a bi-weekly basis, with fun international snacks!
Summary: Geography Club is a club that promotes and celebrates global and human geography. This club is perfect for people who love to learn about relevant geographical topics or just love geography. A place everyone is welcome to celebrate the globe!

Name: Geriatrics Interest Group
Description: The Geriatric Interest Group (GIG) plans to introduce medical students at UMMS to both geriatric medicine and geriatric psychiatry and the importance of these specialties. The organization will host seminars, facilitate faculty mentorship, and encourage students to shadow faculty who specialize in the fields of geriatrics. The goals of GIG are to foster a specific interest in geriatrics, while also emphasizing the wide-ranging nature that a background in geriatrics has for all medical professionals. Early exposure to the principles of geriatric medicine and psychiatry will create better future-physicians as they treat older adult patients.
Summary: The goal of the Geriatric Interest Group (GIG) is to introduce medical students to the complexities and importance of geriatric medicine and geriatric psychiatry through a variety of educational experiences.

Name: German Club at the University of Michigan
Description: German Club's mission is to unite students with an interest in German culture and language and to promote this passion throughout campus, especially in the form of joint events and activities with other language clubs. In addition to hosting a special cultural event every month, we meet weekly at a time and location detailed by email and displayed on our website for an informal get-together called "Stammtisch" to speak in German (all levels welcome!) and increase our knowledge of German culture.
Summary: German Club's mission is to unite students with a passion for German culture and language and to promote the spread of German culture across campus, especially in the form of cross-cultural exchanges with other language clubs.

Name: Gimble A Cappella
Description:
It all began in early 1997 when a group of University of Michigan Arts Chorale members got together to sing some a cappella music. After much debate and many poetry recitations, the group adopted the name "Gimble in the Wabe" from Lewis Carroll's poem, Jabberwocky. Since first performing in April of 1998, the group’s name has been refined to Gimble A Cappella, and has evolved into the self-proclaimed quirkiest a cappella group on campus! Each year, Gimblers unite to host 3 concerts and can frequently be seen performing at various events on campus and around the country during their annual spring tour. 

Gimble released 7 studio albums on CD before their recent releases on streaming platforms. In 2017, they released a 4-song EP, “XX,” in celebration of their 20th anniversary. Featuring hits like “If I Go” and “I’m with You”, it motivated a wave of new releases. Singles “Dancing On My Own” and “715 - CR∑∑KS” debuted in 2018, followed by “Fallingwater” and “when the party’s over” late in 2019. In 2020, they released their 5-song EP “home,” aptly named both for the home they shared together and the unmistakable familial atmosphere of the group. Shortly thereafter, Gimble returned with powerhouse covers of Brandi Carlile's "The Joke" and Hozier's "Movement". Gimble is excited to continue recording their original arrangements for many years to come!

Going strong in its 27th year, Gimble A Cappella continues the tradition with a few fresh faces and a continued passion for a cappella music. Check out our Youtube channel and follow our Instagram page @gimbleacappella for up-to-date information!
Summary: Gimble is an all-gender a cappella group that sings music from a wide variety of genres. We love singing and entertaining while having fun!

Name: Girl Gains at the University of Michigan
Description: Our mission is to promote female weight lifting and empower women to feel strong and beautiful in a judgment free community. Whether you’re a dedicated gym goer or a curious beginner, Girl Gains is a college campus-originated organization and an evolving online community here to support you in every stage of your fitness journey.
Summary: Promoting female weight lifting and empower women to feel strong and beautiful in a judgment free community.

Name: Girl Up Michigan
Description: Girl Up is a United Nations Foundation Campaign that was launched in 2010 to ensure that girls in developing countries are educated, healthy, safe, counted, and positioned to be the next generation of leaders. Through fundraising and advocacy, Girl Up Michigan aims to empower others to get involved and teach the Ann Arbor community that girls around the world matter. Visit our website at https://girlupmichigan.org or our instagram @girlupmichigan to learn more!
Summary: Girl Up Michigan aims to empower others to get involved, teach their communities that girls matter and make sure that girls in developing countries are educated, healthy, safe, counted and positioned to be the next generation of leaders.

Name: Girls in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
Description:
Girls in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (GEECS) is a student organization that encourages the professional, academic, and social development of women in technology. Founded in 2002, GEECS focuses on connecting women in tech and creating a supportive environment for all of its members and alumni. 

In an effort to promote the education and success of technologically inclined women, GEECS reaches out to individuals ranging from middle school girls to graduate students. Currently, the number of women in EECS is steadily declining, and we want to be a part of the change that we hope to see. 

GEECS organizes a variety of social, professional, and academic events for our members. To see what events we are holding, please take a look at the calendar below. For even more information, feel free to check out the GEECS Facebook page and subscribe to our weekly emails. 

To join, fill out this form to get added to our email list and start attending our events! Check out our website here: geecsumich.com 
Email us at geecs.officers@umich.edu for any additional questions!
Summary: GEECS is an organization dedicated to supporting female students pursuing degrees through the EECS department, including degrees in Computer Science, Data Science, Computer Engineering, and Electrical Engineering! Email geecs.officers@umich.edu for info!

Name: Girls Who Code at UM DCMB
Description:
Founded by doctoral students in the Department of Computational Medicine and Bioinformatics (DCMB) at the University of Michigan, our Girls Who Code Club seeks to provide a collaborative and supportive environment for high school women of all skills levels and backgrounds interested in learning how to code. Due to the research expertise of our graduate student Facilitators, our Club curriculum is focused on computational data analysis and the Python programming language. Participants will learn core coding concepts and implement their new skills in a data science capstone project of their choosing.

We also plan and volunteer at various science K-undergraduate outreach opportunities in the greater Ann Arbor area. We launched a Data Science Summer Experience in Detroit in summer 2019. For more information please visit our website http://umich.edu/~girlswc.
Summary: Founded by doctoral students in the Department of Computational Medicine and Bioinformatics (DCMB) at the University of Michigan, our organization runs a Girls Who Code Club, provides K-undergraduate outreach, and runs a Data Science Summer Experience.

Name: Girls Who Code Loop @ UM
Description: Girls Who Code Loop @ UM is an organization affiliated with the national nonprofit organization, Girls Who Code which is a nonprofit organization that aims to support and increase the number of women in computer science. We hope to help the process of closing the gender employment difference in technology and change the image of what a programmer looks like.  We are here for anyone who is interested in tech, regardless of skill level, major, or experience.
Summary: GWC @ UM is an organization established in order to promote females and underrepresented folk in the computer science field.

Name: Global Brigades
Description:
Global Brigades is the world’s largest student-led global and sustainable development organization. Since 2004, Global Brigades has mobilized thousands of students and professionals through nine skill-based programs that work in partnership with community members to improve quality of life in under resourced regions while respecting local culture.

The mission is to resolve global and economic disparities by empowering student volunteers, local professionals, and community members in a collaborative holistic approach to sustainable development. 

The Global Brigades chapter at of Michigan has three of the eight brigades; Dental, Medical, and Public Health.
Summary: Our mission is to empower student and professional volunteers to offer a variety of clinics and consultations, facilitate sustainable solutions, and ultimately promote our holistic model in under-resourced communities in Central America and Africa.

Name: Global CO2 Initiative Student Association
Description:
Our mission is to build a diverse network of students with tangible interest and involvement in the carbon removal community. Each facet of our organization grapples with the task of getting carbon sequestration and utilization recognized and implemented as a mainstream climate solution, and shifting the sources of carbon for everyday living from fossil to non-fossil sources. We seek to incorporate students from all different majors, including engineering, business, climate and sustainability, art and design, and public policy, and have the flexibility to expand into different departments based on the interest and expertise of our members.

We strive to create leaders on campus who will impact industry, government, and academia through their accomplishments during and after their college experience. Above all, we hope they can enhance the global perception of carbon removal as a promising climate solution through their advocacy and responsibility to sustainable action.
Summary: We are a multidisciplinary organization involving undergraduate and graduate students in educational opportunities within the field of carbon removal, such as seminars, technical projects, professional development, and community outreach.

Name: Global Health Alliance at the University of Michigan
Description:
Our Model

We believe that a sustainable partnership model is the best way to maximize impact and minimize the sometimes harmful iatrogenic effects of non-profit work. We are sustainable by maintaining long-term partnerships (5+ years), working towards partner organizations reaching self-sufficiency and sustainability of their own. We also believe in true partnership, a collaboration between two organizations and two communities in which both parties are equally heard, acknowledged and involved in decision-making processes. By purposefully working with these shared ideals in mind, we empower our partners to improve the health of their own communities.

 

About Us

Our chapter is an independent student-run organization, and is one of the first in the nation to partner with 2 non-profit organizations. We partner with Joy-Southfield Community Development Corporation in the Cody Rouge neighborhood of Detroit, MI. We help run nutrition workshops, their community gardening program, and youth education programs in order to provide healthy food and nutrition education to the community. We also partner with Green Umbrella school in the Putsor Community near Phnom Penh, Cambodia, which believes in the potential of today's youth. Green Umbrella provides quality education to disenfranchised families, in order to achieve sustainable development, facilitates leadership programs to enhance confidence and unity within the community, and leads livelihood workshops for adults and English classes for children. We raise an annual amount of $6,000 for our international partner and assist with their assessment research and education modeling during our 3-week long trip every summer. At our Monday night meetings, we plan fundraising and volunteer events and hold discussion-based lessons about public health issues.

As a Global Health Alliance chapter, we have partnered with student organizations at MIT, UChicago, UW-Madison, and Tufts to create a collaborative network of clubs with similar goals.  We share ideas in order to create the best organizations at our respective campuses; however, all of our fundraising, partnerships, and general meetings are managed separately.
Summary: Global Health Alliance engages in a sustainable partnership model to improve health locally and abroad. We strengthen the movement for global health equity by empowering our partners Joy-Southfield in Detroit, MI and Green Umbrella in Cambodia.

Name: Global Investments Committee
Description:
We are a close-knit student organization focusing on the global economy and financial markets. Using the diversity of our membership base as well as the resources in the Stephen M. Ross School of Business and Tozzi Trading Floor, we aim at providing an unparalleled hands-on learning experience to our fellow members by organizing valuation workshops, speaker series, trading simulations, etc. In addition, we utilize our network to organize recruiting events with companies in the financial services industry.

Diversity is a focal point of our club. With members from different countries and backgrounds, you will learn more about different cultures and get yourself more prepared for the rapidly globalizing world!
Summary: Close-knit student organization focusing on the global economy and financial markets. Using the diversity of our membership base as well as the resources in the Ross School of Business, we aim at providing an unparalleled hands-on learning experience.

Name: Global Scholars Program
Description:
GSP is an academically supported living-learning community that provides sophomore, junior, and senior University of Michigan students the opportunity to engage with both U.S. and international students on campus and around the world.

Students will learn about global issues from multiple cultural perspectives. Also, coursework and collaborative projects will assist students as they begin to develop and hone their intercultural communication skills.

Finally, Global Scholars residents are encouraged to study, intern, or work abroad to reap the full rewards of the program—learning from intercultural experiences and engaging with the world.
Summary: The Global Scholars Program (GSP) prepares sophomore, junior, and senior University of Michigan students to be interculturally competent global citizens, champions for meaningful change, and innovative leaders of tomorrow.

Name: Global Surgery Student Alliance
Description:
Global Surgery Student Alliance (GSSA) aims to educate undergraduate students about global healthcare inequities. GSSA has multiple chapters at different undergraduate universities and medical schools. The undergraduate U of M chapter will host events, workshops, seminars, and webinars with healthcare professionals. The chapter will also organize and facilitate resume workshops and study groups. The events that GSSA hosts will be educational in nature. For example, there are many activities we may host including but not limited to suturing events, hackathons, emergency medicine clinics, and panels. Members of GSSA also have the opportunity to foster connections with U of M medical school students and practicing medical professionals in the global health field.

Health care is a human right, and GSSA hopes to act as a resource for students to learn about providing care to patients. Though GSSA is a pre-health/med organization, it also highlights the multidisciplinary nature of healthcare. Healthcare is a complex topic that does not simply start with going into the doctor’s office. It also involves other disciplines, such as pharmacy, business, public policy, and engineering. We believe that students of differing academic and intellectual backgrounds are vital to the success of our organization. 

We hope to inspire future healthcare providers, encouraging them to think about healthcare and surgery from a broader, more global perspective.
Summary: Our mission, as the U of M chapter of Global Surgery Student Alliance, is to provide valuable resources about global surgery and related health inequities that will help engage, excite, and inspire our members in their healthcare aspirations.

Name: Go Blue Wear Pink
Description:
If you would like to become involved, please email hmkatz@umich.edu. We are not notified when you just press "join."

 

Go Blue Wear Pink is a student-run organization at the University of Michigan that raises money to fund breast cancer research at the U-M Rogel Cancer Center. Since 2007, students have raised over $360,000 to accelerate groundbreaking research at one of the nation’s leading cancer research centers. 

We all know someone who has been affected by cancer, whether a close friend, family member, or friend of a friend. And we have all seen the debilitating effect that this disease can have on patients and the people who are supporting them.

Please join us in easing the burden of cancer by making a donation. Your support will improve and save lives. No donation is too small, because every dollar represents the next step in the search for a cure.
Summary: Go Blue Wear Pink at the University of Michigan was founded in 2007 to help raise money and awareness for Breast Cancer Research at the University of Michigan Rogel Cancer Center.

Name: Golden Theatre Company
Description: Golden Theatre Company is a student-run organization created to expand the knowledge of and opportunity for musicals in the classical canon through the production and performance of a fully staged musical, while maintaining an environment that is safe, innovative, and diverse for each of the students involved. To accomplish our mission, we will produce one musical per semester in both the Fall and Winter. These will consist of shows written in the Golden Age era of musical theatre, as well as any and all musicals that are typically sung in the classical, or “legit” style.
Summary: Golden Theatre Company is a student-run theater organization that focuses on Golden Age Musical Theatre and musicals performed in the classical style.

Name: Good News Christian A Cappella
Description: We are a Christian organization on campus that is dedicated to spreading the gospel of Jesus Christ to this campus through music. We rehearse twice weekly and hold a concert each semester, in addition to performing at other smaller venues over the course of the semester. Good News is a wonderful community of fun people who love singing and are dedicated to serving Christ.
Summary: We are a Christian A Cappella group that is dedicated to bringing the good news of the gospel to the U-M campus through music.

Name: Goodness Day
Description: The premise behind Goodness Day is simply to spread goodness and kindness, and student orgs can do that in a lot of different ways.  It is set up similarly to Festifall with tables lining the Diag, and groups often give out goodies or have some kind of fun activity for passers-by.  Each year we have fun activities to brighten everyone's day!  Although the purpose of the day is not recruitment, it can be a good way to spread awareness about your organization, to connect with other organizations, and to just get your name out there a little more.
Summary: The premise behind Goodness Day is simply to spread goodness and kindness, and student orgs can do that in a lot of different ways.  It is set up with tables lining the Diag, and groups often give out goodies or have some kind of fun activity to do.

Name: Gowns for Good at the University of Michigan a Member of Operation PROM National Network
Description: Gowns for Good seeks to provide underprivileged teenage girls in the Ann Arbor area with the opportunity to actualize their dreams of confidently attending prom in a dress they love.  Prom is a pivotal right of passage for teenagers, and is an event many students look forward to every year.  However many girls cannot afford to buy a new dress, and may not attend the special night for that reason.  Gowns for Good puts on a giveaway event in the early spring that serves as the prom dress shopping experience that is so exciting for girls. The event is completely funded by donations and volunteer action, please send us a message if you would like to participate!
Summary: Gowns for Good at UofM is a community-service organization that facilitates a prom dress drive in order to provide local high school girls who cannot otherwise afford a dress with one that they love, for free.

Name: GradCru
Description:
GradCru is a graduate student chapter at U-M of the international mission organization “Cru”, which has a ministry presence on 2,696 campuses in the U.S. and 191 nations worldwide.

GradCru is for American and International Master, Ph.D., and Professional School graduate students. Many graduate students who are involved are single, there are marrieds and even some with children. GradCru is very diverse racially/ethnically, from around the U.S. and world, social/economic backgrounds, academic programs from across campus, and more ways. We think you’ll feel welcome and fit well.

We are very active on campus in many different ways — and have a lot of fun together! You are welcome to participate to whatever extent you desire and what fits with your often rigorous schedule, with no pressure (you get enough pressure just being in grad school).

At our core (our mission statement), GradCru is a graduate community that seeks to stimulate and support each other to (1) live out authentically and (2) communicate meaningfully our faith in Jesus Christ in the midst of the University. And we want to think deeply about the integral relationship of our faith and our academics. We value and promote “4 E’s”:

• E1: ENCOUNTER Jesus fully. (Romans 1:16)
• E2: ESTABLISH Christian grad students in their faith. (Colossians 2:6-7)
• E3: EQUIP grad believers with effective ministry skills. (Ephesians 4:11)
• E4: ENTRUST Christian grads to reproduce these distinctives around the world (2 Timothy 2:2)

Here is a listing of much of what GradCru provides (and is described throughout the website):

• Bible Study Groups • Social Events (e.g., board game nights, parties, sports, dinners) • Prayer/Prayer-Walks • Campus-wide and Individual Outreach • Spiritual Mentoring/Discipleship • Ministry Philosophy and Skills Training • International Lecture/Mission Trips (e.g., Filter of Hope to Cuba) • and More!
Summary: GradCru is a graduate student community that seeks to stimulate and support its members to live out authentically and communicate meaningfully their faith in Jesus Christ in the midst of the University.

Name: GradTONES
Description: The purpose of the GradTONES is to provide an opportunity for graduate students throughout the University of Michigan to rehearse and perform unaccompanied vocal music from a variety of popular musical genres, as well as to foster interdepartmental interaction and camaraderie across graduate programs.
Summary: GradTONES A Cappella is a co-ed singing group composed entirely of graduate students currently enrolled at the University of Michigan. The latter half of this name is an acronym standing for "Troupe Of Needlessly Educated Singers".

Name: Graduate Economics Society
Description: The Graduate Economics Society exists in order to promote a positive and productive environment for graduate students in the Department of Economics at the University of Michigan. To this end, we work to facilitate social events among graduate students and greater interaction among the students, and between students and faculty members. In addition, we help coordinate office allocations and other managerial responsibilities. Finally, we seek to represent the graduate students to the department, helping to engage the department on issues that may arise, and improvements to the policies and program of graduate study in economics.
Summary: The Graduate Economics Society exists in order to promote a positive and productive environment for graduate students in the Economics Department at the University of Michigan.

Name: Graduate Rackham International
Description:
The mission of Graduate Rackham International (GRIN) students is to develop an inclusive and diverse student-run organization to improve the experience of all graduate students, especially those who identify as international and/or multi-ethnic/racial/cultural, at the University of Michigan. As an organization we support connections and social involvement among students across cultures and programs of study. Our programming supports professional development, mentorship, outreach, DEI, and other initiatives to benefit primarily graduate students - both international and domestic students with international interests at the University. We aim to provide these students with a voice and a platform for advocacy on issues that affect their success and well-being.

To find more: http://grin.rackham.umich.edu/
Summary:
Graduate Rackham International (GRIN) is a student-run organization that aims to provide support for all graduate students, esp those who identify as international or multi-ethnic, at the University of Michigan.
Find more: http://grin.rackham.umich.edu/

Name: Graduate Research, Outreach, Workshops, and Evaluation
Description: GROWE is a student volunteer organization with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center at the University of Michigan. GROWE seeks to exist as a peer educator space for graduate students, who are interested in learning more about creating respectful spaces inside of their own learning communities.
Summary: GROWE is a student volunteer organization with the Sexual Assault Prevention and Awareness Center at the University of Michigan. GROWE seeks to exist as a peer educator space for graduate students, who are interested in creating respectful communities.

Name: Graduate Society of Black Engineers and Scientists
Description:
The Graduate Society of Black Engineers and Scientists (GSBES), formerly known as The Society of Minority Engineers and Scientists – Graduate Component (SMES-G), serves as an academic and social network for Black graduate students within the University of Michigan's STEM community.
