Standing on its three pillars of Professionalism, Philanthropy, and Social Engagement, PGN offers an abundance of opportunities to promote professional and personal development.
Summary: Phi Gamma Nu is a premier business professional fraternity. Standing on its three pillars of Professionalism, Philanthropy, and Community, PGN offers an abundance of opportunities to promote professional and personal development.

Name: Phi Iota Alpha Latino Fraternity Inc.
Description:
The Beta Upsilon Chapter of Phi Iota Alpha Fraternity, Inc. has the objective to create a lighthearted yet professional environment for men across the masculinity spectrum. The BY chapter achieves this by cultivating spaces that allow for conversations around masculinity. During these talks, we come face to face with ourselves and our members to break down the toxic traits we internalized. We practice patients, communication, and respect with one another to provide a space where honest mistakes turn into learning experiences.

The goal is to have these well-rounded and motivated members produce unique events that support the community in new and innovative ways. The members accomplish this by allowing their personal interests to integrate into the events. This allows each member’s personality and passion to shine through their hard work.
Summary: The Beta Upsilon chapter of Phi Iota Alpha is a work-hard, play-hard Latine-based fraternity that focuses on cultivating trailblazers, professionals, and intercultural thinkers. Brothers strive to embody our 3 ideals: Strength, Integrity, and Friendship.

Name: Phi Lambda Sigma
Description:
Phi Lambda Sigma is the Pharmacy Leadership Society, with its members consisting of the foremost leaders in the field of pharmacy.  At the University of Michigan, the Delta Kappa Chapter has the following mission and vision for its organization:

Mission: To empower the next generation of pharmacy leaders by providing innovative opportunities for growth and promoting the recognition and development of leadership

Vision: To become recognized, both locally and nationally, as a premier leadership group by challenging the status quo and driving positive change in the student body, community, and profession
Summary: Phi Lambda Sigma is the Pharmacy Leadership Society.  The Society has a mission to encourage, recognize, and promote leadership in pharmacy.  Special attention shall be given to the development of leadership qualities.

Name: Phi Sigma Pi
Description:
Phi Sigma Pi National Honor Fraternity is a member of the Professional Greek Council and focuses its efforts on increasing the knowledge of its Brothers, providing service to the community, and creating a positive social environment for its members.  

Phi Sigma Pi is a fun, welcoming community that gives you the best of all that social, professional, and service fraternities have to offer. 

Please reach out to us as pspbetaalpha@gmail.com if you have any questions or are interested in joining!
Summary: Phi Sigma Pi National Honor Fraternity aims to promote the acquisition and dissemination of information and knowledge through scholarship, leadership, and fellowship.

Name: Phi Sigma Rho - Eta Chapter
Description:
Phi Sigma Rho is a social sorority for women in engineering and technical science fields. Our chapter values are friendship, scholarship and encouragement, and we strive to embody those values is everything we do, both as a chapter and as individuals. Our National Philanthropy is The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, and we work locally with the Girls Scouts of America.

 

To join our email list for Fall 2023 please click here:https://forms.gle/XFDWZdFWWhUvHJiE6
Summary: Social sorority for women in engineering and STEM.

Name: Photonix/UAC
Description:
We use glowsticks as our primary medium to create exciting visual art in live performances. We utilize glowsticks along with strings, staffs, and any other implement we can find to manipulate light in a fascinating way. We glowstick in order to express ourselves and to create a sense of wonder in our audiences, and to establish camaraderie with all club members as we pursue our shared goal. Self-discipline, self-reliance, and self-expression applied in a team-oriented setting is what Photonix is all about. 

https://youtu.be/sEboII2AyHc
Summary: We are a small team of artists who rely on the interplay between light and dark to paint ethereal portraits during live performances. We glowstick to enjoy it for what it is and to inspire awe and wonder in our audiences.

Name: Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Student Interest Group
Description: Student organization dedicated to increasing awareness and engagement with the field of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation among medical students at the University of Michigan.
Summary: Student organization dedicated to increasing awareness and engagement with the field of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation among medical students at the University of Michigan.

Name: Physics Graduate Council
Description: Grad Council was established for the express purpose of bringing students and faculty together for department-wide events, and collaborating with the U-M Physics leadership to strengthen the graduate program. Grad Council seeks to facilitate communication between graduate students and other members of the department, including faculty and administration. Above all, Grad Council serves as a resource for the graduate students in the Physics Department and works towards implementing suggestions and addressing concerns that are brought up by graduate students.
Summary: Grad Council seeks to improve the graduate experience in the Physics Department, both academically and socially, encouraging camaraderie and providing a confidential avenue for students to make suggestions and voice concerns.

Name: Pi Sigma Alpha (Political Science Honor Society)
Description:
Pi Sigma Alpha is the National Political Science Honor Society open to juniors and seniors in the Political Science department. We work with the Department to provide our members with opportunities to grow professionally and academically. These events include our Professor-Student dinner, career workshops, lectures, as well as more casual events. Membership is extended to applicants who fit the criteria set forth by Nationals and our local chapter.


The current requirements for membership are:

  1. Completion of at least half the credits required for the bachelor's degree (i.e. junior or senior standing)
  2. Completion of at least 4 courses for juniors and 5 courses for seniors, and of work in political science, including at least one upper-division course (you do not have to have declared a political science major as long as this requirement is met).
  3. A GPA of 3.5 in all courses in political science
  4. Maintenance of general scholarship sufficient to place the student in the top one-third of the class
  5. An overall GPA of 3.5
  6. Transfer students must have completed four courses in political science at the time of application

Would you like to partner with Pi Sigma Alpha to host an event? Please contact Aleksandra Kole at akole@umich.edu.
Summary: Alpha Upsilon Chapter of Pi Sigma Alpha, the National Political Science Honor Society

Name: Pi Sigma Epsilon
Description: Pi Sigma Epsilon is a professional fraternity that prepares individuals for success in their business career through professional, social, and philanthropic experiences. We are proud to offer the unique opportunity to participate in consulting projects with local and global businesses. Our tight-knit community, dedicated members, and diversity of academic majors provides for a community equipped to help you discover and prepare for the business path that is best for you.
Summary: Pi Sigma Epsilon is a professional fraternity that prepares individuals for success in their business career through professional, social, and philanthropic experiences.

Name: Pi Tau Sigma
Description: PI TAU SIGMA members are chosen on a basis of sound engineering ability, scholarship (upper 35%), personality, and probable future success in their chosen field of Mechanical Engineering. There are three grades of membership: Honorary, Graduate, and Active. Honorary members are technical graduates actively engaged in engineering work; or members of mechanical engineering faculties. Graduate membership is conferred upon persons who would have been eligible had Pi Tau Sigma been established earlier in schools not having chapters, or upon those continuing graduate study. Active members are selected from the junior and senior mechanical engineering classes at their respective schools whose mechanical engineering curriculum must be accredited by ABET.
Summary: Pi Tau Sigma (PTS) is the International Mechanical Engineering Honor Society and is a member of the Association of College Honor Societies. There are chapters at universities in almost every state of the United States.

Name: Pinky Swear PACK at the University of Michigan
Description:
Since 2003, Pinky Swear Foundation has supported families with a child battling cancer through direct financial aid for basic needs, as well as experiences that create emotional support including:Orange Envelope Program—For families with a child who has been newly diagnosed with cancer, providing a virtual ‘hug’ and small financial gift delivered right to their mailbox. All-Star Fund—A fund that covers a mortgage or rent payment, pays for gas or groceries, or other non-medical needs a family may have while caring for a child with cancer. Memorable Family Experiences—All-Star
Weekends and other unique activities that provide emotional support and quality time together out of the hospital. Pinky Swear Pantry—On-site food pantry at children’s hospitals with grab-and-go options for families so they can stay near their child with cancer and ease their financial burden.
Summary: Pinky Swear PACK is an organization that helps support children diagnosed with pediatric cancer and their families emotionally and finically. As a PACK on campus this includes Card Making, Fundraisers, spreading awareness, and All-Star engagement.

Name: Plaintiff's Law Association
Description:
Plaintiff's firms offer a middle ground for law students who wish to do well and do good. Plaintiff-side attorneys hold corporations accountable, represent the interests of victims, consumers, and injured persons, fight for civil rights, and ensure equal access to justice. Junior associates at plaintiff's firms often gain more substantive litigation experience than their Big Law counterparts while earning salaries higher than their non-profit peers. It’s no surprise, then, that plaintiff-side careers are on the rise.

Students, however, often have a difficult time researching and networking with plaintiff-side firms. This is—in part—because most plaintiff’s firms do not follow consistent hiring cycles. Likewise, only a handful of plaintiff-side host on-campus interviews.

In turn, law students must rely on alumni, their peers, and many a Google search to network with plaintiff's attorneys and hunt down employment opportunities. And that's only accounting for those students who know these opportunities exist. Many law students, and especially 1Ls, have no idea that plaintiff's firms are a viable career path in the first place.

The Plaintiff’s Law Association (PLA) is dedicated to fill this gap, supporting students who want to learn about, network with, and pursue careers at plaintiff-side law firms. PLA will host educational events, job fairs, and maintain an up-to-date networking guide for all students. PLA will also build community by connecting students to those with similar career interests.
Summary: The Plaintiff’s Law Association (PLA) is dedicated supporting students who want to learn about, network with, and pursue careers at plaintiff-side law firms.

Name: Planning and Architecture Research Group
Description: The Planning and Architecture Research Group (P+ARG) was created over a decade ago by and for the doctoral students at the Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning. Our mission is to enhance the academic and social experiences of students engaged in research across the college’s programs through collaboration. We seek to foster community among planning and architecture students in order to sustain an exchange of ideas within and between our disciplines and subfields. We are open to all students at the University of Michigan who are interested in engaging with issues of the built environment. To sustain our interdisciplinary conversations, we receive funding from both Rackham and Taubman College with which we hold regular workshops and events throughout the year as well as our bi-annual conference.
Summary: P+ARG is composed of students of the built environment, mainly in Urban Planning and Architecture but also open to students in all disciplines. We organize forums for sharing research across disciplines plus casual and social events. Let's collaborate!

Name: Plant Futures at the University of Michigan
Description: Plant Futures at the University of Michigan is open to students of all levels and academic programs. The University of Michigan Chapter focuses on education and multi-disciplinary learning around building sustainable, just, and plant-centric food systems. Beyond education and community building, another core focus of the chapter is to serve as a space for members to secure meaningful professional development opportunities, mentorship, and career opportunities within plant-centric food systems. Students will be able to connect with non-profit and for-profit organizations addressing exciting opportunities within the sector.
Summary: Plant Futures at the University of Michigan focuses on education and multi-disciplinary learning around building sustainable, just, and plant-centric food systems while serving as a space to explore opportunities with organizations in the sector.

Name: Plastic Surgery Interest Group
Description: The Plastic Surgery Interest Group (PSIG) allows medical students at the University of Michigan to learn about and experience the ever-growing field of plastic surgery. PSIG hosts events, many coordinated with the M1 anatomy sequence, to supplement learning and stimulate interest in plastic surgery. Michigan boasts one of the top plastic surgery programs in the country, and our team of accomplished mentors will help to set up advising and shadowing opportunities so that students may experience the field and develop competitive applications for the match process.
Summary: PSIG is a medical student interest group that provides medical students with opportunities to learn about the field of plastic surgery and to develop competitive applications for the match process.

Name: Poetry Slam
Summary: Poetry Slam at the University of Michigan

Name: Pokémon Go UMich
Description: Since 2016, people all over the world have enjoyed Pokémon Go for its combination of bringing the magical world of Pokémon into the real world. Yet, the greatest aspect of the game was its ability to bring people together and enjoy each other's presence in the outside world. Ever since its debut, Pokémon Go has dedicated itself to focusing on its community and how every member interacts with one another while playing the game. Even with the pandemic, Pokémon Go was still about exploring the world and being with one another. Our mission is to make our own community at the University of Michigan, to make new friends and enjoy new places in Ann Arbor, together.
Summary: A club designed for players of Niantic's 2016 phenomenon Pokémon Go, or any fans of Pokémon or going outside and exploring Ann Arbor. Our club's mission is to make a strong community of Pokémon Go players in Ann Arbor through the University.

Name: Portait of South Asia
Description: POSA (Portrait of South Asia) is a South Asian focused magazine with a purpose to help shine light on continuously neglected narratives of the South Asian student population at the University of Michigan. As we see more South Asian representation in all forms of media, various stereotypes become reinforced through editing and refining South Asian stories to fit Western aesthetics. Through elaborate photoshoots and recording stories, POSA aims to create a physical relic of the South Asian experience in a way that is inclusive, authentic, and fulfilling. POSA’s goal is to capture the essence of being South Asian to help build a tangible history for the South Asian community at U of M.
Summary: Our goal is to help capture the multilayered essence of being South Asian. What it means to be South Asian is unique to everyone, and we want to capture what that means for you. Through photographic narratives, we hope to authentically amplify previous.

Name: Portlab
Description: Created by grad students, Portlab is a newer, growing student organization that started out with a strong data science focus. We've proudly provided 3 projects to 6 teams this past academic year, and we plan to continue offering real-world project opportunities to our members. Currently, we seek to grow our leadership team to streamline this process and grow Portlab as a whole. Join us for mentorship, workshops, projects, leadership roles, and more!
Summary: Portlab is a platform and network that aspires to connect, educate, and inspire students through impactful projects.

Name: Poverty Solutions
Description: Poverty Solutions is a University of Michigan initiative that aims to prevent and alleviate poverty through action-based research that informs policymakers, community organizations, government entities, and practitioners about what works in confronting poverty. Students bring new insight, knowledge and opinions to our work, enhance our interdisciplinary and collaborative approach, lend support and capacity to our projects and activities, and help to promote campus-wide engagement.
Summary: Poverty Solutions is a University of Michigan initiative that aims to prevent and alleviate poverty through action-based research that informs policymakers, community organizations, government entities, and practitioners about what works in confronting p

Name: Pre-Anesthesiologist Assistant Association
Description:
• An Anesthesiologist Assistant or AA works in an Anesthesia Care Team and provides anesthesia under the supervision of a licensed anesthesiologist. The care team may also consist of CRNAs or Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetists, in which they share a similar role to AAs and assist physician anesthesiologists. Anesthesiologist Assistants have a master's level education, meaning they go to graduate school for 2-3 years following undergrad. 
  • To find more information about Anesthesiologist Assistants, visit American Academy of Anesthesiologist Assistants and American Society of Anesthesiologists 
  • As a member of this organization, you will benefit from:
    • Volunteering at Michigan Medicine, blood drives, and at the World Medical Relief Headquarters 
    • Research opportunities; Attending conferences and getting the opportunity to present your research there
    • Shadowing Anesthesiologists, CRNAs, AAs and networking with them
    • Resume and cover letter building workshops
    • Panels with Anesthesiologists, CRNAs, AAs where they discuss tips for the interview process, enhancing your CASAA application, personal statement, and more
    • Chance to meet with admissions officers for AA schools

Fill out the member interest form to be added to the email list! Member Interest Form 

Follow our Instagram for updates!
Summary: Pre-AA or CAA organization that aims to help and unite aspiring anesthesiologist assistants to gain valuable experiences, while also promoting the profession to a large community to those interested in the healthcare field.

Name: Pre-Dental Association
Description:
Our goal is to assist students of all ages and interest levels to better understand current oral healthcare issues, dental school admission processes, and dental school itself. Through volunteer activities, social outings, and mass meetings, each member also receives many opportunities to meet and network with dental school professors and students, admissions representatives from various schools, and fellow pre-dental students.

We provide information on the many dental careers, the various details of the application process, and how to get more involved as pre-dental student. We also work to provide a multitude of opportunities such as open house visits, talking with a panel of dental specialists, and outreach events in the local community. To learn more about our upcoming events, please sign up for our weekly email list at https://pdaumich.weebly.com/
Summary: An organization for students interested in a career in the dental field. We seek to provide leadership, social, and educational opportunities for our members. We are committed to aiding prospective dental students throughout their undergraduate years.

Name: Pre-Med Hub
Description:
Pre-Med Hub seeks to serve the University of Michigan’s competitive pre-med community by providing easy-to-access advice and resources for course selection, MCAT preparation, and more. Our advisors are juniors and seniors who have gone through the difficult weeder courses and are passionate about their goal of becoming a physician. We would love to guide and encourage you as you pursue your pre-med journey as well.  

Ask us a question, visit  our facebook page, read our Q/A archives and blog posts (and subscribe here for notifications), or talk to us privately through peer advising! Regardless of how you connect with us, we hope you leave with less confusion and panic than you came in with. We’ve been there. You’re going to be just fine.
Summary: We are a student-run platform at the University of Michigan that seeks to serve students by providing a space to ask and answer questions pertaining to all things pre-med. WE DO NOT HAVE A MEMBERSHIP, PLEASE VISIT OUR WEBSITE TO USE US AS A RESOURCE.

Name: Pre-Medical Club
Description:
Please refer to our Canvas page to join PMC! To be added to our Canvas page, please use this link: https://umich.instructure.com/enroll/EYWXPP. To be added to our Groupme for regular updates, please use this link: https://groupme.com/join_group/88926217/yVsvxQPl. Follow us on Instagram @pmc_um!

The mission of the Pre-Medical Club at the University Of Michigan is to maintain an outstanding and diverse student body that has a strong interest in the health sciences and a demonstrated commitment to service and continued learning.  

The Pre-Med Club at the University of Michigan consists of active members and an executive board. One may attain active membership by completing the following requirements: (1) Paying dues ($10 New Members, $5 Returning Members), (2) Earn 5 points by the end of the semester through participating in various events. Participating in the PMC Mentorship program, attending the Alternative Spring Break trips, or volunteering in the WHSP program will grant members 4 points. Active members can apply for eboard positions, participate in the physician shadowing program, receive free Access to Medical School Admissions Requirements (MSAR), and receive a 20% discount on all Princeton Review MCAT classes.

We offer the following opportunities for all members:

Philanthropy partnerships with Wigs 4 Kids, Freedom House Detroit, Center for Success, Mothers2Mothers, Autism Awareness
Volunteering opportunities with the Wolverine Health Sciences Program, Food Gatherers, Relay for Life, Detroit Partnership Day, VA Hospital, Hope Clinic, Glacier Hills
PMC Formal
Alternative Spring Break 
Medical School Training and Exploratory Program (M-STEP) medical school visits and tours 
Mass Meetings with special guest speakers
Mentorship program 
Physician shadowing with local physicians  
Social events
and many more!

For more information please refer to our Canvas page or follow us on Instagram @pmc_um! To be added to our Canvas page, please use this link: https://umich.instructure.com/enroll/EYWXP. To be added to our Groupme, please use this link: https://groupme.com/join_group/88926217/6ZViVZja

For specific questions, contact us at premedclub@umich.edu.
Summary: By providing numerous medically related opportunities, our club takes pride in supporting every individual to reach his or her potential, and to become the leading physicians of tomorrow. Come join one of the biggest Pre-Med Clubs in the country!

Name: Pre-Optometry Club
Description: Our goal is to educate those interested in Pre-Health careers on the benefits in the field of Optometry. We provide peer support, presentations from accredited optometry schools, meetings with optometrists, and much more!
Summary: Our goal is to educate those interested in Pre-Health careers on the benefits of Optometry! We provide support from peers, presentations from accredited optometry schools, meetings with optometrists, and much more!

Name: Pre-Pharmacy Student Organization
Description:
Pre-Pharmacy Student Organization (PPSO), the only pre-pharmacy organization at the University of Michigan, is a student-run club for undergraduate students interested in careers in pharmacy. Whether you’re interested in working at your neighborhood pharmacy, in a health care system, or researching the latest drugs, PPSO can help you get there. 

Through a combination of professional development, career exploration, academic success, social, and networking activities, we work together to make the most of our undergraduate years and prepare for the next steps in our education and our eventual place in the exciting and dynamic field of pharmacy. 
We are future pharmacists, preparing for the future of pharmacy.
 

2023-2024 Executive Board Members
President: Alexander Dodson
Vice President: Allison Borland
Secretary: Lanny Lo
Treasurer: Kylie Schramke
Service Coordinator: Noelia Dulo
Membership Coordinator: Sydney Barnes
Social Events Coordinator: Lauren Cupchak
Summary: Our goal is to create a network of pre-pharmacy students to help each other prepare for pharmacy school, the application process, and a future career in healthcare.

Name: Pre-Physical and Occupational Therapy Club
Description:
Our mission is to foster a community of Pre-Physical & Occupational Therapy students to establish support, resources, and assistance in the quest to enter the fields of Physical & Occupational Therapy.

Commitment to the organization includes attending monthly meetings, participating in fundraising events for the club, and engaging in community service and shadowing events.

Monthly meetings feature guest speakers such as current physical & occupational therapists (as well as speech-language pathologists, strength & conditioning coaches, & more!), current graduate students, academic advisors, graduate school admissions officers and representatives from GRE prep services.

We offer job shadowing opportunities that connect students with physical therapists around the Ann Arbor area and through the University of Michigan Health System.

Our organization is an outlet for networking with peers and alumni, allowing you to gain advice from upperclassmen regarding schools, applications, & PTCAS/OTCAS, as well as allowing you to collaborate with other students in Kinesiology & pre-health courses.

For more information, you can send our president Abby Heisler a message at abbyheis@umich.edu. You can also check us out on Facebook and Instagram at @preptotclub or by searching "Michigan Pre-Physical and Occupational Therapy Club"!
Summary: The Pre-Physical and Occupational Therapy Club is a pre-professional organization that supports and encourages undergraduate students interested in pursuing Physical & Occupational Therapy and related fields as a career.

Name: Pre-Physician Assistant Club
Description:
What is a Physician Assistant?

Physician Assistants (PAs) are health care professionals who practice medicine under the supervision of a licensed physician.  PAs provide physical exams, order and administer tests, make diagnoses, and treat illnesses and injuries.  PAs work in a variety of settings including hospitals, long-term care facilities, private practices, and surgical centers.  They are qualified to practice in virtually every specialty area and are allowed to prescribe medicine in all 50 states and the District of Columbia. 

Executive Board

President: Alexa Donahue - alexadon@umich.edu

Vice President: Grace Cole - grcole@umich.edu

Secretary: Laura Nowicki - lauranow@umich.edu

Treasurer: Katie Crowe - ktcrowe@umich.edu 

Communications Chair: Sawyer Darish - sndarish@umich.edu 

Activity Director: Ian Kadwani - ikadwani@umich.edu 

Activity Director: Lindsey Zousmer - lzousmer@umich.edu 

Phlebotomy Class Coordinator: Molly Zidar - mqzidar@umich.edu

Advisor: Megan Morsi, PA-C megrum@med.umich.edu

Advisor: Natalie Nichols - nnatalie@umich.edu

The Pre-PA Club aims to consolidate information and resources concerning physician assistant program admission requirements, application procedures, and health experience opportunities. Our goal is to inform members about the history and purpose of the profession while providing familiarity with the health care system.

The Pre-PA Club intends to provide all members with opportunities to meet with professionals in the field, to tour local Physician Assistant Programs, and to discuss issues regarding the profession.  The club also intends to hold social events for members and fundraising events to aid in our local philanthropic efforts.

We hold approximately 7 meetings per semester.  Meetings are typically held at 7pm, bi-weekly on Wednesdays.

As a member, you will benefit from:

  • Meeting workshops regarding prerequisite classes and the CASPA application
  • Discounts on GRE Prep Courses and Materials through the Princeton Review

  • Interview and Personal Statement tips and practice

  • E-mails about job openings

  • PA panels and speakers

  • Participation at the Ronald McDonald House, local blood drives, Adopt-a-Family and more

  • Networking for summer opportunities ie. summer camps, patient care, mission trips, etc.

  • Restaurant fundraisers

  • Program directors from regional PA programs and much much more!

The dues are only $10 per year or $5 per semester 

Active members are identified as anyone who has paid their dues for that academic year or semester and has accrued 5* active membership points (per semester) by attending meetings and participating in volunteer events. Note that at least 2 of the 5 points MUST come from participation in volunteer events. Each meeting and volunteer event count as 1 point each. 


*This number is subject to adjustment based on the number of volunteer events offered each semester; volunteer activity points are adjusted to accommodate the duration of the event.

You can access our Notion with all of our resources and information here: UMich Pre-PA Club Notion 

or with this link: https://developing-paper-2a0.notion.site/Pre-PA-Club-at-UMich-43473689b6fa487d9f07b3b6ef7ada99 

For more information, please email the Pre-PA Eboard at umich-prepa@umich.edu

If you wish to be added to the email list and/or club roster, please email Laura Nowicki at lauranow@umich.edu. The roster on MaizePages is outdated.
Summary: The mission of the Pre-Physician Assistant Club is to provide students aspiring to be Physician Assistants the means to reach their goals. The club aims to bring Pre-PA students, community PAs, and a variety of PA schools together.

Name: Pre-Speech and Hearing Club
Description: The purpose of the University of Michigan Pre-Speech and Hearing Club is to provide members with resources and various forums to expand their knowledge of the Speech and Hearing Sciences Field. The club aims to provide members with information and opportunities regarding graduate school requirements, field options, course options, current studies, etc. We organize events with guest speakers and Question-and-Answer sessions with people who have experience with Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology schooling and within the field of Speech and Hearing Sciences. We also strive to create a community in which Pre-Speech and Hearing students feel supported in their professional journeys, not isolated by the lack of a university department.
Summary: The purpose the Pre-Speech and Hearing Club is to provide members with resources and various forums to expand their knowledge of the Speech and Hearing Sciences Field.

Name: Pre-Student Osteopathic Medical Association
Description: Pre-SOMA is a club dedicated to pre-med students who are interested in pursuing osteopathic medicine.  The club provides members with volunteer and job shadowing opportunities, osteopathic medical school tours, and a chance to learn more about osteopathic medicine.
Summary: Pre-SOMA is a club dedicated to pre-med students who are interested in pursuing osteopathic medicine.  The club provides members with volunteer and job shadowing opportunities, osteopathic medical school tours, and a chance to learn more about osteopathy

Name: Pre-Surgical Club
Description: The undergraduate Pre-Surgical Club aims to provide students with exposure to a career in surgery within the various specialties and enable them to delve into the field of medicine at a deeper level than otherwise offered through traditional undergraduate opportunities. Through offering a variety of speakers, panels, and workshops for the undergraduate community and organization members, the Pre-Surgical Club aims to develop an individual’s passion for discovery within and knowledge of surgery and medicine as a whole. Further opportunities include viewing of surgical procedures as well as the ability to attend lectures and conferences detailing their advancement in the field. Students expressing interest in research related to surgery may potentially pair with a surgeon to work alongside them and present their research in an annual event. Lastly, the club aims to start an outreach program to youth in high school in order to spark their interest in a health career, specifically related to surgery.
Summary: The organization provides members with significant exposure to the field of surgery through providing a variety of speaker panels, workshops and shadowing opportunities.  Our mission is to empower students to explore their passion at a meaningful level.

Name: Pre-Vet Club
Description:
On a campus full of pre-med students, the Pre-Vet Club intends on increasing the opportunities available to pre-vet students. Volunteer opportunities will be facilitated both for animal and veterinary experiences. Members will learn both about the veterinary field as well as the application process and requirements. The Club intends on giving members a thorough knowledge of the veterinary field by visiting and learning about many types of veterinary medicine ranging from small animal to wildlife. Additionally, members will network and provide the necessary resources to adequately prepare for veterinary school.

For more information about our club or future careers in veterinary medicine, feel free to reach out to Verena Wu our Events Director, Costa Sideratos our Treasurer, Ava Ryder our Vice President, or Aneesa Berner our President.
Summary: The Pre-Vet Club is for students interested in pursuing a career in veterinary medicine. The Club focuses on providing volunteer opportunities, networking, updated veterinary information, and pre-vet advising.

Name: Prison Birth Project
Description: Prison Birth Project is a student organization at the University of Michigan that operates at the intersection of reproductive and restorative justice. We aim to ensure legal reproductive healthcare access inside and outside of the carceral system. We also advocate for humane conditions of confinement and smooth reentry to society. Using anti-racist and inclusive practices, PBP engages in research projects, educational initiatives, community outreach, and political organizing. Sign up for our newsletter here.
Summary: Prison Birth Project is a student organization at the University of Michigan that aims to inspire students and community members to advocate for incarcerated mothers and birthing people.

Name: Privacy and Technology Law Association
Description:
The Privacy & Technology Law Association (PTLA) focuses on technology policy issues, including security and surveillance, privacy rights in the digital sphere, and internet openness.

In addition to hosting events to foster a vibrant intellectual dialogue on how technology affects the legal framework in which we live, we organize various career panels and other social activities for JD candidates, LLM students, faculty members, and individuals from throughout the University of Michigan community.
Summary: The Privacy & Technology Law Association (PTLA) focuses on technology policy issues, including security and surveillance, privacy rights in the digital sphere, and internet openness.

Name: Program in the Environment
Description: Program in the Environment (PitE - like might) has one major, Environment BA/BS, and five minors - Environment, Sustainability, Food & the Environment, Energy Science & Policy, and Water & the Environment. The PitE major and minor(s) give students the ability to explore the natural sciences (biology, ecology, and geology), humanities (literature and philosophy), and social sciences (policy, activism, and business) under the umbrella of environment. The program’s interdisciplinarity allows students to discover and connect how each of these disciplines shapes the human relationship to our planet. PitE gives each student the choice to pick their own adventure, selecting courses that are of particular interest to them. Our program allows students to go into the field for engaged learning experiences, including internships, field stations, and study abroad, which will prepare them for future employment and graduate school.
Summary: Program in the Environment has one major, Environment BA/BS, and five minors - Environment, Sustainability, Food & the Environment, Energy Science & Policy, and Water & the Environment.

Name: Program in the Environment Club
Description:
PitE Club is an enriching community for students interested in environmentalism, especially PitE students. Together we learn about environmental topics, participate in sustainability focused volunteering, and provide valuable resources toward professional development both at UofM and in the broader workforce. Specific events include the SEAS student mentorship event (BEAR), No Impact Challenge, Pizza with the Professors, Midnight Breakfast, and sustainable based social events (like environmental student conferences, hiking, and camping).

Our weekly meetings include environmentally themed presentations, planning for events, and the occasional potluck. Past events have included a beeswax wrap making event, a trail-mix bar, succulent terrarium workshop, documentary screenings, and a virtual herb garden making tutorial. 

Additionally, the club coordinates volunteer opportunities in Ann Arbor for PitE Club members such as volunteering at the Campus Farm, Recycle Ann Arbor, the Maize and Blue Cupboard, the Creature Conservancy, Huron River Watershed Council, and more.

In short, PitE Club seeks to connect its members to enriching environmentally-focused experiences and education on campus and in the greater Ann Arbor community.
Summary: PitE Club functions as the liaison between PitE students and the academic department. Together we host events centered around topics like environmental learning, volunteering and professional development.

Name: Project HEAL at the University of Michigan
Description: The mission of Project HEAL at the University of Michigan is to deliver prevention, treatment financing, and recovery support for individuals with eating disorders through training and education. We will promote the mission and values of Project HEAL: Help to Eat, Accept and Live, a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization that has over 40 Chapters throughout the United States, Canada, and Australia. Through speaker events, fundraising, and spreading eating disorder treatment awareness we hope to reduce the stigma surrounding eating disorders and direct others to resources for recovery.
Summary: The mission of Project HEAL at the University of Michigan is to deliver prevention, treatment financing, and recovery support for individuals with eating disorders through training and education.

Name: Project Hispañola
Description:
Our student-run organization is partnering with the New Horizons Foundation, a nonprofit organization that works with Haitian and Dominican communities in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. This first year, our engineering team will research, explore, and build shredder and extruder machines so we can truly get a grasp of the recycling process. Our goal is to use these types of machines to create a low-cost and sustainable method of producing bricks from recycled plastic waste. With these bricks, we aim to tackle the plastic pollution issue and improve the living conditions for people in need of more sufficient housing.

 

At our core, we are driven to make a lasting impact. Recognizing the importance of education in driving lasting change, we are committed to supporting the New Horizons Foundation's programs that promote environmental awareness among children and communities. We plan to organize fundraisers at the University of Michigan, celebrating the rich cultures of Haiti and the Dominican Republic. Together, we drive sustainable change, reshaping the engineering landscape with a profound focus on culture, community, and responsible resource management.
Summary: Project Hispañola integrates engineering, culture, and community outreach to address issues of insufficient housing and plastic pollution in Haitian and Dominican communities.

Name: Project Music
Description:
The purpose of this student organization is to push our creative skills to the limit and revolutionize the music industry and the way we create music. This club has two main objectives in mind to achieve our purpose:

Our club is devoted to invent, fabricate and perform experimental and conventional musical instruments and gear. We intend to design several experimental instruments each term and perform throughout the university as often as possible. This organization will give students a great opportunity to gain valuable experience and integrate multiple and diverse skills such as design, manufacture, music, engineering and more. 

The second objective of this club is to bring students together to play conventional and unconventional musical instruments. This organization will provide a space for students to make music and enable them to find other musicians with similar interests.
Summary:
This is a club dedicated to designing and fabricating experimental musical instruments and audio gear.
More Information At: http://michiganprojectmusic.com

Name: Project Nutrition
Description: Project Nutrition is established with the purpose of increasing awareness of healthy eating. College students often struggle with finding accessible, healthy recipes. We aim to create a platform for students to share healthy recipes in order to promote healthy eating.
Summary: College students often struggle with finding accessible, healthy recipes. Project Nutrition was established to raise awareness of healthy eating. We will meet weekly to share resources related to nutrition, and we have created a virtual platform as well.

Name: Project RISHI at University of Michigan
Description: Project RISHI (Rural India Social & Health Improvement) is a non-profit organization whose mission is to promote the sustainable development and growth of rural Indian communities. In partnership with local community members and social enterprises, we identify issues central to our target communities and provide the resources to implement solutions through extensive field research and on-campus initiatives.
Summary: Project RISHI is a national non-profit organization whose mission is to promote the sustainable development and growth of rural Indian communities.

Name: Project Sunshine
Description: Project Sunshine aims to spread sunshine to pediatric patients to restore a sense of normalcy to the pediatric healthcare environment, and make sure that kids have their childhood.With over 40 established chapters across the US and internationally, Project Sunshine at the University of Michigan will train you to volunteer with children at St. Joe's Hospital and beyond! All majors are welcome, as long as you have a passion to help kids be kids, regardless of the condition of their health!
Summary: Project Sunshine at the University of Michigan aims to spread sunshine to pediatric patients to restore a sense of normalcy to the pediatric healthcare environment, and make sure that kids have their childhood.

Name: Project WriteOn
Description: Project WriteOn seeks to create a community of writers from varying backgrounds. Our purpose is to employ writing as a medium of self and group healing. Our organization hopes to promote writing in various forms outside of academic uses through individual and group activities geared towards populations at the VA Hospital, C.S. Mott Children's Hospital, Nursing Homes, elementary schools, other student organizations etc. We are driven by the idea that writing is not an innate skill, but rather an art and practice that simultaneously stimulates our minds and enhances our communication skills. We, the members of Project WriteOn, do hereby establish this constitution.
Summary: Project WriteOn seeks to create a community of writers from varying backgrounds. Our purpose is to employ writing as a medium of self and group healing and promote writing in various forms outside of academic uses.

Name: Propel Business Club
Description: Propel Business Club’s mission is to educate different student groups both in and outside of Ross on the value of the intersection between business and social impact, and to provide an engaging, hands-on experience with different local businesses and organizations to build impactful programs, initiatives, and projects to serve the community.
Summary: Propel Business Club aims to provide students who are passionate about social impact and positive business with meaningful projects with real businesses and organizations motivated towards positively impacting the greater community.

Name: Protect Life at the University of Michigan
Description:
Protect Life at the University of Michigan is an inclusive organization that advocates for the value and protection of all human life. We are a diverse and open community, united in our commitment to fostering a culture that upholds the dignity of every individual.

 

As a non-partisan, non-sectarian, and non-profit group, we seek to educate and raise awareness about various issues related to life, such as unplanned pregnancy, adoption, abortion, euthanasia, infanticide, embryonic stem cell research, and the death penalty. Through informative resources and discussions, we aim to promote understanding and empathy among our peers.

 

At Protect Life UM, we engage with students and the wider public, encouraging dialogue and reflection on pro-life matters. Additionally, we provide support to pregnant and parenting students, ensuring they have access to resources and assistance throughout their journey. By fostering connections and building a supportive community, we aim to cultivate a campus atmosphere that values and respects the inherent worth of every human being.
Summary: We are the leading pro-life group on campus. We are devoted to having conversations with students about life issues, educating our campus, and offering our support to pregnant and parenting students so they are empowered to choose life in their lives.

Name: Psi Chi Honors Society in Psychology
Description:
Psi Chi is an international honor society whose purpose is to encourage, stimulate, and maintain excellence in scholarship of the individual members in all fields, particularly in psychology, and to advance the science of psychology.

There is an application process to become a member. Learn more at our website.
Summary: Recognizing and promoting excellence in the science and application of psychology.

Name: Public Benefits Advocacy Project
Description:
Under the supervision of attorneys from Legal Services of South Central Michigan, we hold weekly office hours to help clients navigate the public benefits system, serving as advocates to ensure they receive the benefits to which they are entitled.

Members typically attend one or more two-hour intake sessions per month at community centers in the Ann Arbor area, and/or a few two-hour office hours sessions per semester. We provide substantive and skills training for new and returning members during the beginning of each semester in cooperation with attorneys from the Michigan Poverty Law Program. Since COVID, most of PBAP's activity has taken on a remote format with members reaching out to clients via phone and email after they have reached out to us for assistance. 

PBAP provides law students with a valuable opportunity to participate in community service, learn about public interest and administrative law, and develop skills such as compassionate client interviewing and effective communication with government agencies.
Summary: Members of the Public Benefits Advocacy Project (PBAP) assist clients in completing applications for food stamps and Medicaid, and follow opened cases to ensure accurate processing.

Name: Public Health Association
Description: We are a student organization that aims to provide opportunities allowing for the education and discussion of public health while building a strong community of students that support one another in their exploration of and contribution to the field of public health. To achieve this, we host educational speakers such as current UM School of Public Health faculty and leading professionals in the field, provide community service projects and fundraisers, offer admissions and professional development workshops and organize social events, all to raise awareness of and advocate for public health issues.
Summary: An organization for future leaders in the field of public health.

Name: Public Health Student Assembly
Description:
The Public Health Student Assembly (PHSA) is the student government of the University of Michigan School of Public Health (SPH). Our primary goal is to foster relations between the various departments of the school and to assist student organizations in hosting school-wide events. PHSA also serves as a liaison between the student body and the school's administration.

Specific responsibilities of PHSA include:

  • Raising awareness of issues relevant to the SPH student body and giving the student body a forum for addressing concerns
  • Coordinating and promoting social, educational, and community service events relevant to the SPH student body
  • Offering resources and guidance to SPH-affiliated student organizations
  • Providing representation on appropriate SPH administrative committees
  • Serving as a general liaison between the student body, student organizations, and SPH
  • Supporting SPH administration in activities relevant to the student community
Summary: The Public Health Student Assembly (PHSA) is the student government for the University of Michigan School of Public Health.

Name: Public Health Students of African Descent
Description: PHSAD strives to create an atmosphere wherein academic and professional excellence can coincide with the interests of populations of African descent. We strive to disseminate and exchange information and concerns of marginalized groups in the field of Public Health and to serve as a network and support system for educational and professional purposes. In addition, we aim to disseminate knowledge to the southeast Michigan community and support the community through philanthropic endeavors and service.
Summary: PHSAD is a student organization centered around support, advocacy, and service that is committed to creating and fostering a sense of community amongst populations of African descent within and outside of the School of Public Health.

Name: Public Service Internship Program
Description: The University Career Center's Public Service Intern Program (PSIP) prepares undergraduate students to obtain summer internships in Washington DC, educates them to build career development skills, connects them with alumni mentors, informs them about career options through speakers panels & employer visits in DC, and supports participants while living in our nation's capitol. The University Career Center is proud to offer PSIP, the oldest and largest summer intern program in the country!
Summary: The University Career Center's Public Service Intern Program (PSIP) prepares undergraduate students to obtain summer internships in Washington DC.

Name: Puentes
Description: The mission of Puentes is to create an equitable space that centers the intersectional identities of incoming and current Latinx graduate students across schools, departments, and disciplines at U-M. We strive to foster a space of community, healing, and empowerment, where students feel supported and equipped to advocate for their needs and the needs of their community during and beyond their academic tenure at U-M.
Summary: Latinx Graduate Student Organization

Name: Puerto Rico Student Association
Description: PRSA is an undergraduate community of Puerto Rican students at UofM (although not restricted to Puerto Ricans). PRSA hopes to cultivate an environment where Puerto Rican culture can be celebrated.
Summary: PRSA is an undergraduate community of Puerto Rican students at UofM (although not restricted to Puerto Ricans). PRSA hopes to cultivate an environment where Puerto Rican culture can be celebrated.

Name: PULSE
Description:
PULSE is a student-run organization that aims to explore and promote the intersection between wellbeing and identity across the campus community through peer interactions and strategic programming. PULSE uses a holistic model of wellbeing in our conversations in order to generate a more complete picture of what wellness could look like and determine how our unique identities can affect those various aspects of wellness. As a PULSE member, students will have the opportunity to attend trainings and forums that facilitate conversations about wellness & identity-focused topics so that members can better equip themselves to handle the relevant and prominent trends across campus. Our goal is to empower members through conversations and community building in order to produce effective cross-campus programming and high-impact projects that address those prominent wellness & identity trends and provide solutions for the overall community, while fostering personal growth and creating a community for our members. 

To find out more about the mission of PULSE and how to become a member, please email askpulse@umich.edu for more information or visit our website!
Summary: PULSE is a student-run organization focused on the intersection of wellness and identity. We emphasize student-based change both inwardly within ourselves as members and outwardly by promoting health and holistic wellbeing throughout the campus community

Name: Punjabi Student Union
Description:
The Punjabi Student Union is an organization that aims to bring together students of Punjabi descent and those interested in Punjabi culture and heritage. The PSU works to create a supportive community on campus and to promote cultural awareness and understanding.

The Punjabi Student Union holds regular cultural events and activities that showcase the rich history and traditions of Punjabi culture. They also organize community service events to give back to the local community and raise awareness about important social issues. Whether it's through religious, social, or educational events, the Punjabi Student Union is dedicated to promoting a positive and inclusive environment for all members.
Summary: The Punjabi Student Union is a student-run organization dedicated to promoting Punjabi culture and heritage at the University of Michigan.

Name: Pure Dance
Description:
Pure is a microcosm of the Michigan experience: we provide dancers with the opportunity to work with others who have had different training that have a broad spectrum of strengths and backgrounds. Creating and maintaining an open and inclusive environment is extremely important to us. There are no financial barriers to joining Pure (we don’t charge dues), and we welcome students regardless of race, gender, and sexual orientation. We recognize that the world of dance is often extremely demanding, both mentally and physically, and we strive to provide a safe environment where our members can express themselves without the pressure of conforming to the “ideal dancer” archetype. The closeness of our community is a large part of this commitment: we make a strong effort to organize social events so that our dancers have the opportunity to build friendships.

Pure Dance meets twice a week at the Intramural Sports Building to rehearse our student-choreographed pieces in anticipation of our annual showcase, which occurs at the beginning of the winter semester. We choreograph two large-group pieces and give our members the opportunity to choreograph small-group pieces each year. We perform these pieces at events around campus as well as at our annual showcase. Please reach out if you are interested in auditioning! here
Summary: Pure Dance is a tight knit, student led group of passionate dancers from a variety of disciplines and backgrounds. Pure provides its members with opportunities to perform, choreograph, hold leadership positions, and participate in social events!

Name: Qingyun Chinese Music Ensemble at U of M
Description: Qingyun is established for the purpose of providing opportunities for performance experience and allowing students with previous experience in Chinese traditional instrument to continue their passion. We are determined to bring Chinese traditional music to the University of Michigan and therefore promote cultural and musical diversity on campus.
Summary: Qingyun is established for the purpose of providing opportunities for performance experience and allowing students with previous experience in Chinese traditional instrument to continue their passion.

Name: Quant-UM
Description: Quant-UM is a way for students to share experiences based on a shared interest in quantum information science, engineering, and technology, by introducing students to quantum science resources, research, events, and media.
Summary: Quant-UM is a way for students to share experiences based on a shared interest in quantum information science, engineering, and technology, by introducing students to quantum science resources, research, events, and media.

Name: Quantitative Investment Society
Description:
QIS is for students interested in applying quantitative models and algorithmic thinking to financial markets. Our members are comfortable with university level math and one or more programming languages. Our goal is to provide members the resources to develop trading strategies and a space to exchange ideas about financial markets.

To learn more, visit www.qisumich.com
Summary: The Quantitative Investment Society (QIS) provides University of Michigan students a collaborative environment to learn about quantitative finance, financial markets, and risk management through the creation and management of a student-managed fund.

Name: Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences
Description: The Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences (QMSS) program seeks to unite Michigan’s excellence in social science with the current revolution in the data science. The minor in Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences will train the next generation of social scientists in the methods needed to harness all types of quantitative data in order to generate new insights and solutions to the problems of today and tomorrow.
Summary: The Quantitative Methods in the Social Sciences (QMSS) program seeks to unite Michigan’s excellence in social science with the current revolution in the data science.

Name: Rackham Student Government
Description:
The Rackham Student Government (RSG) is the student government that represents the thousands of graduate students in the Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies. RSG consists of 30 representatives who come from a variety of disciplines across campus as well as three executive officers. In addition to the elected members of the RSG Board, any graduate student may be a member of RSG's committees and/or serve as an associate representative on the Board. For more information, please visit http://rsg.umich.edu

 

Programs

See our website: http://rsg.umich.edu RSG Elections are held each November and March. Graduate students DO NOT need to run for office to be a part of RSG. While voting members of the RSG Board (our legislature) must be elected by the student body, affiliate representatives, committee members, and event volunteers DO NOT need to run for office. For more information about these activities, please email rsg-exec@umich.edu
Summary: Rackham Student Government is the student government that represents the 9,000+ graduate students on campus. Please visit our website, rsg.umich.edu for more information on our advocacy activities, funding, and events or follow us on social media.

Name: RallyCap Sports
Description: We are the University of Michigan chapter of RallyCap Sports and we believe people with special needs deserve the chance to play sports! We provide year-round, recreational sports for children and young adults with special needs in the Ann Arbor community. Our volunteers are made up of University of Michigan students, who match-up one-on-one with local participants with special needs for each sporting activity. Our activities take place on the University of Michigan campus and surrounding area. About RallyCap
Summary: We are the UM chapter of RallyCap Sports and we believe people with special needs deserve the chance to play sports! We provide year-round, recreational sports for children and young adults with special needs in the Ann Arbor community.

Name: Ratio Christi
Description:
Many university students wrestle with burning questions about purpose, faith, and identity. Ratio Christi provides a safe place to ask questions about the Christian faith--and gives resources to answer them with confidence.

We unite faith and reason to give students thoughtful reasons for following Jesus Christ. We seek to help Christians work through their doubts, and ultimately share Christ with their peers.

We are a Christian organization, but we welcome people of all views. We hope to be challenged by others and to share our beliefs with those who disagree.

Core Values:
Evangelism. We are evangelistic at heart. Our goal is to share the good news of Jesus on the college campus.

Training. We equip Christian students to answer the objections to faith that they hear.

Debate. If needed, we will directly fight against the ideas and worldviews that seek to pull people away from Christianity.

Fellowship. We’re just as quick to give a hug as we are to give an argument.
Summary: Ratio Christi (Latin for ‘The Reason of Christ’) is a global movement of university students and faculty seeking to unite faith and reason and present historical, philosophical, and scientific reasons for following Jesus Christ.

Name: RC Players
Description: The RC Players is a student-run theater group based in the Residential College. But fret not, you don't have to be a member of the RC to participate; anyone can join! Our performances are held in East Quad's Keene Theater. Each semester, the RC Players put on a variety of shows--ranging from sketch comedy (Evening of Scenes) to 24-hour theater (Red Eye), to full-length productions. So whatever your interest is, we've got a place for you to pursue it.
Summary: The RC Players is a student-run theater group housed in East Quad, courtesy of the Residential College at The University of Michigan. The group presents several productions each semester ranging from short sketch shows to full-length productions. Join!

Name: Reach Consulting Group
Description:
Reach Consulting Group (Reach) is a student-run, non-profit consulting organization that thrives on providing advisory services in technology, strategy, finance and management consulting. Our mission is to equip our members with real-world consulting experience, honing their skills in data analysis, problem-solving and effective communication. Through pro-bono engagements with both local and national clients, we strive to make a positive impact in the business community while staying at the forefront of technological advancements. Join Reach to be part of a collaborative and growth-focused community, where you can make meaningful connections with industry professionals and develop expertise applicable to careers in the consulting, finance and technology sectors.

For updated recruitment information and more about Reach Consulting Group, visit our website: https://www.michiganrcg.com.
Summary: Reach is a student-led technology consulting organization equipping members with real-world experiences. We make a positive impact with pro-bono projects and foster growth in a collaborative community. Join us at https://www.michiganrcg.com.

Name: Recreational Sports
Description: Whether your goal is fitness, exercise, strength training, well-being, competition, adventure, friendship, or fun we've got you covered. Learn more by visiting our website.
Summary: Learn about how you can "Move Your Way to Well-Being with Rec Sports!

Name: Red Tree
Description: Red Tree is a Christian organization that believes that a person has a relationship with God through the person and work of Jesus Christ. We believe the Scriptures of the Old and New Testaments to be the Word of God and source to direct us how we may glorify and enjoy God. People who hold to other belief systems are always welcome to be involved with us and to worship and serve with us.
Summary: Red Tree meets students in this unique stage of life by exploring how the Bible impacts every area of life. We strive to be a place where students can ask hard questions of the Bible and grow in faith.

Name: Redeemed Christian Fellowship
Description: You are welcome. We preach the Gospel of the Lord Jesus Christ, teach the word of God from the Bible, and care for people. Come and experience the Lord Jesus Christ with us. Thank you.
Summary: We preach the Gospel of the Lord Jesus Christ, teach the word of God from the Bible and care for people

Name: Redeemer Ann Arbor Student Group
Description: R A2 is a group of students connected to Redeemer Ann Arbor Church who gather for Bible study, community, and encouragment.
Summary: The purpose of Redeemer A2 Student Group is to provide spiritual encouragement and information to U of M students about Redeemer Ann Arbor.  Redeemer Ann Arbor is a church plant located close to the campus of U of M (www.RedeemerA2.org).

Name: Redefined
Description:
Redefined is a Christ-centered service organization made up of people who love each other and want to live out God-given mission to serve our communities.

 

We believe that service is one of the greatest acts of love and, as Christians, that it is part of our call to serve not as a ‘one time thing’, but as a lifestyle. Through partnerships created with local organizations in the greater Ann Arbor, Ypsilanti, and Detroit area, we will form specialized teams with individuals dedicated to service. We will also spend time in fellowship to grow closer with one another.
Summary: Redefined is a Christ-centered service organization made up of people who love each other and want to live out God-given mission to serve our communities.

Name: Refill Your Cup
Description: In this org, we will have two meetings a month. The first meeting will be an open discussion on a specified topic i.e. burnout and what it looks like, being POC at a PWI, the trials of being a part of the LGBTQ+ community, etc. The second meeting will be a sort of activity with the goal of letting go of pent-up stress. The goal of this org is to serve as a kind of rejuvenation forum where members can revive their mental bandwidth/capacity lost due to high-impact life events such as school stress, personal issues, etc.
Summary: This org is a kind of rejuvenation forum where members can revive their mental bandwidth/capacity lost due to high-impact life events such as school stress, personal issues, etc.

Name: Reformed University Fellowship
Description: RUF is a Christian ministry for the glory of God and the good of UM. We are learning how to love God, love ourselves, love other people and love the University of Michigan. Learn more here!
Summary: RUF is a community of students at UM who are learning how to experience, embody, and extend the love of Jesus in the world.

Name: Relevé Dance Company
Description: Relevé Dance Company is a jazz, lyrical, and contemporary student-run organization at The University of Michigan. Relevé aims to provide a place for those with a passion of dance to come together to dance, to choreograph, and to learn. Through dance, Relevé hopes to create a space where members can bond with one another, while expanding their experience as dancers and choreographers.
Summary: Relevé Dance Company is a jazz, lyrical, and contemporary student-run organization at The University of Michigan. Relevé aims to provide a place for those with a passion of dance to come together to grow as dancers and choreographers.

Name: Rem & Company
Description:
Rem and Company is a social impact initiative that offers pro-bono consulting services to small businesses impacted by COVID-19. There are tons of small businesses in AA and the greater Detroit area that are struggling to navigate the post-pandemic world.

 

When helping small businesses, we want to place an emphasis on working with minority and female owned businesses, as well as non-profits. Rem on Campus is a great way to get hands-on consulting experience and work alongside professionals at top companies.

 

We are looking to work with driven and creative students who have a passion for making meaningful change. You will be joining a community of students from all different majors, backgrounds, and class years.
Summary: Rem and Company is a social impact initiative that offers pro-bono consulting services to small businesses impacted by COVID-19. Our primary business focuses include strategy, marketing, social media, UI/UX, and financial management.

Name: Res Sista Loquitur: Women of Color Coalition
Description: Res Sista Loquitur: Women of Color Coalition is dedicated to creating a supportive community for women of color at the law school through social activities and mentorship. We also seek to prepare our fellow women of color to navigate the legal profession through panel discussions and professional development events. Although Res Sista is a space created for women of color, we welcome and encourage membership of all people who are interested in learning more about the challenges women of color face within the law school, the legal profession, and society at large.
Summary: Res Sista provides a supportive space for women of color at the law school to further their personal and professional development.

Name: Research Unraveled
Description:
Research Unraveled offers students the chance to read the latest medical news and academic journal articles on topics including health policy, bias in healthcare, bioethics, medical humanities, and technologies used to streamline healthcare. In biweekly meetings, members discuss relevant topics related to medicine and later post discussion summaries on social media and the Research Unraveled's website to inform the public of healthcare news and advances.

https://maras.webstarts.com/index.html?r=20210514141301
Summary: Discuss, read, and write about medical news! Research Unraveled helps students understand and spread awareness of medical news through group conversations and by creating posts for the organization's website/Instagram.

Name: Reseller's Society
Description: The mission of the Reseller's Society club is to create a supportive space to learn about how to become a third party reseller and to operate a start-up business purchasing and reselling consumer products. The Reseller’s Society aims to promote and facilitate networking among its members and also share resources and information through educational workshops, online discourses, lessons in how to operate software bots to purchase items, and one on one mentoring. A strong interest in entrepreneurship is preferred, while no prior business experience is required.
Summary: The Reseller's Society is a student-led organization which provides educational resources and networking opportunities for students interested in learning how to resell consumer goods as well as students already immersed in the industry.

Name: Residence Halls Association
Description: Student Government in the Residence Halls at the University of Michigan.
Summary: Student Government in the Residence Halls

Name: Residential College Forums
Description: Residential College (RC) Forums provide a medium through which students can establish and strengthen relationships with other students and RC Faculty/Staff while engaging in the various social communities that surround them. Through the creative expression of ideas (in the form of any number of creatively themed projects) RC students will be able to share experiences that can have a positive impact upon the RC Community, the University of Michigan, and the city of Ann Arbor. Each individual forum is based on a specific interest and through will be able to attract students with similar interests and creative an environment in which students can find a space to discuss issues, interact socially, or work towards a goal they have regarding an interest they have. Beyond intra-forum affairs, the RC Forums also strive to pose profound and real "inter-forum" connections through events and discussions. Forums afford students the opportunity to actively engage in their education by encouraging them to take an innovative approach to problem solving and by preparing them for effective and responsible engagement in the real world.
Summary: The RC Forums are several student-led groups based on special interests. These include Letters Forum, Sex Forum, Health and Wellness Forum, Creative Writing Forum, Film Forum, Food Forum, RC Review, and Diversity & Politics!

Name: Resource Association of Premedical Students
Description: The Resource Association of Premedical Students is a premedical club that aims to provide academic resources, guidance, and professional development skills to its members. We are an inclusive organization whose mission is to ease the intimidation of being an undergraduate premedical student at U of M.
Summary: This club aims to provide resources for premedical undergraduate students in the form of regular meetings, guest speakers, club events, and exclusive classroom necessities.

Name: Retail Club at The Ross School of Business
Description:
The Ross Retail Club (RRC) was established in 2003 at the Ross School of Business. RRC welcomes BBAs and non-BBA students who are interested in learning about and building careers in the luxury goods and retail industries. RRC brings students, alumni, and companies together through alumni networking, guest speaker events, corporate presentations, and company on-site visits. We provide members with career resources to help them get started and succeed in various retail and luxury goods disciplines. 


Our primary focus is on CPG companies, apparel, mass merchandising, retail consulting, retail manufacturing, and luxury retailing. In addition, our club addresses a spectrum of business functions, including business operations, finance, general management, marketing, merchandising, strategy, sales and supply chain management.
Summary: To increase awareness & education in the fashion and retail industries among students, to educate students on the various career opportunities within these industries, and to strengthen Ross' position as a top recruiting school for retail companies.

Name: Revolution
Description: Founded in the Winter of 2009, Revolution is the Chinese Yoyo team at the University of Michigan. Blending the traditional pastime of Chinese Yoyo with modern music, Revolution aims to promote Chinese Yoyo/diabolo as a performance art and bring awareness to Asian American culture. As one of the most unique performance teams at UofM, Revolution has performed at some of the biggest events both on campus and off campus.
Summary: To raise awareness of Chinese Yoyo/diabolo as a performance art form and to raise awareness of Asian  American culture through performances and workshops.

Name: RhythM Tap/UAC
Description: Our mission is to promote tap dance as a form of young American culture on campus. We practice and perform at community events throughout the year. We strive for excellence on stage and build lasting friendships in the process.
Summary: We are a student-run, self-choreographed, advanced tap performance group.  Our efforts can be seen in several large performances such as Dance Mix, as well as in our own show, It's TAPpening.

Name: Riley's Way at the University of Michigan
Description:
Riley's Way Foundation is a national nonprofit organization that invests in and supports a youth-led kindness movement, providing young people with the programs, support, and inclusive community they need to thrive as change-makers. 

Forbes Article
Summary: The Riley’s Way U of M chapter is focused on bringing together campus change-makers and like-minded students. This chapter will create opportunities for students to practice leading with empathy and kindness to make a difference on a social impact issue.

Name: Risky Business
Description: Risky Business is the epitome of good times and good tunes. It all comes together for several epic shows each year when we serenade our classmates, faculty members, and the Ross and University of Michigan community with an eclectic mix of our favorite jams. If you like to perform in front of a fanatical cast of groupies (read: your fellow MBAs), then this is the group for you.
Summary: Risky Business is a musical group comprised of MBAs and MBA partners. The group plays multiple shows throughout the school year with songs that span multiple musical artists, genres, and decades.

Name: Robotics Graduate Student Council
Description:
The mission statement of the RGSC is to create an organized group of graduate students in the Robotics Program who are committed to promoting the growth of the Robotics Program at the University of Michigan and to supporting the social, academic, and professional development of these students.  As part of this mission, we strive to:

  1. Foster an environment in which all students have a voice in their education and community. Ensure that voice is heard by coordinating with the students, the College of Engineering and Robotics Program leadership so that the goals of all three parties can be attained.
  2. Create a community for all the graduate students in the Robotics Program by organizing events that promote social interaction and a feeling of comradery among the students.
