Borrowing the template from the world-renowned TED conference, TEDxUofM aims to bring a TED-like experience to the University of Michigan.  The vision is to showcase the most fascinating thinkers and doers, the “leaders and best” in Michigan terms, for a stimulating day of presentations, discussions, entertainment, and art.  The annual conference brings together great minds, brilliant talent, and innovative thinkers who are eager to inform the universe about their passions and dreams for the future. The ideas and stories radiating from the TEDxUofM stage are meant to generate an energy in the audience watching, transforming their perception of the world and provoking them to act upon their own ideas as well as collaborate with those around them.

 

Find out more at our website, tedxuofm.com.

 

Our General team meetings are on Mondays from 7:30-8:30 pm in East Quad room B852. Feel free to attend!
Summary: TEDxUofM aims to galvanize the University of Michigan community by bringing together passionate individuals across all disciplines who believe in TED's motto of "Ideas Worth Spreading."

Name: Thai Student Association
Description:
The Thai Student Association (TSA) at the University of Michigan (UM) is one of the oldest student organizations founded by Thai students in the United States. Established for over fifty years, TSA is a Thai student-based organization which includes Thai and non-Thai members who are interested in Thailand and its culture, politics, people, and other aspects. We have around 100 members including undergraduate and graduate students, visiting scholars and research fellows, building a very diverse group. Other than our various activities at the University of Michigan that have been the social involvement hosted by TSA at UM, our main event of “Thai Night” has been a focal attraction with a joint effort between Thai students at the University of Michigan and Eastern Michigan University (EMU) for many years. We also receive overwhelming support from the Thai community in Michigan, the Michigan Student Assembly, and other local organizations. In the past, our Thai cultural performances and exhibitions have been highly recognized in the community over the years.

In addition, TSA has been working closely with the Center for Southeast Asian Studies and the University of Michigan, along with the Tourism Authority of Thailand to enhance the understanding of Thai and Southeast Asian cultures among the community. We also work in collaboration with other student groups such as Vietnamese, Singaporean, and Indonesian student associations to promote our culture.
Summary: Thai Student Association is an organization that brings together students from Thailand, Thai-U.S. and anyone interested in the Thai Culture. Our goals are to promote a unified community of Thais and share our culture with the UM and Ann Arbor community.

Name: The Accounting Club
Description:
https://www.michiganaccountingclub.com/

Our Mission

Promoting the study and practice of accounting and finance; providing opportunities for self-development, service, and association among members and practicing professionals, and encouraging a sense of ethical, social, and public responsibility.

Our Purpose

  • Encourage students to choose a career within the field of accounting.
  • Stimulate interest and encourage scholarship of students presently in the accounting curriculum.
  • Strengthen the ties between executives in business and students preparing to enter business.
  • Provide students with the opportunity to participate in organizing, planning, directing, and controlling an organization dedicated to the promotion and advancement of the art and science of accounting.
  • Encourage interaction among these college students, faculty and business executives through corporate presentations, educational workshops, and other unique opportunities. The professional and social environments offered to the members of this organization are opportune times for students to learn more about the different fields of business and create various networking connections that will aid in their future success.

Visit our website to become a member!
Summary: Established to aid in the professional development of college students actively interested in accounting, corporate finance and other related fields.

Name: The American Constitution Society at the University of Michigan
Description:
The American Constitution Society (ACS) is a national organization that shapes debate on important legal and constitutional issues through development and promotion of high-impact ideas to opinion leaders and the media; by building networks of lawyers, law students, judges and policymakers dedicated to those ideas; and by countering the activist conservative legal movement that has sought to erode our enduring constitutional values.

At the American Constitution Society at the University of Michigan, we organize discussions featuring prominent legal experts and professionals. We also host special events ranging from our annual Supreme Court Roundup to our periodic small-group Professor Lunches, available to our national members. We are one of the nation's most active ACS chapters and were awarded "Chapter of the Year" at the 2009 national convention and "Chapter of the Week" in 2015 and 2016. We were also awarded the "Programming Award" in 2014, 2017, 2022 and 2023.
Summary: This is the American Constitution Society at the University of Michigan. ACS is a national network of progressive constitutional scholars and attorneys.

Name: The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention at the University of Michigan
Description: Our chapter of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention is part of a national organization of community and campus chapters across the country, created to prevent suicide and provide hope for those affected by suicide. Our campus chapter will serve University of Michigan students by advocating for their mental health, raising and allocating funds towards mental health resources and suicide prevention tools, collaborating with other University of Michigan organizations to improve existing opportunities and host events to educate students about suicide prevention and mental health, and organizing our annual Out of the Darkness walks.
Summary: A student group affiliated and sponsored by the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention to continue suicide prevention, education, and advocacy work on UM's campus, and to continue organizing Out of the Darkness walks.

Name: The American Revival Front
Description: The ARF seeks to make tangible change. Too often, groups talk about making change and then do little to turn their words into actions. We are different. We are an action-oriented group that will make real change here in Ann Arbor and across the state. We believe that our differences are played up, and our commonalities are played down, and that, in reality, we all agree far more than some would have us believe. There are common-sense solutions and actions that we can embrace that will make a difference here and now. We support finding those solutions and acting on them.
Summary: The ARF is an organization dedicated to service and charity through action. We seek to do good works and advocate for the changes we all need to see. We are here to unite people in this polarizing time.

Name: The Auscultations
Description:
Focused H&P
Name: The Auscultations

HPI: a ragtag group of med students with histories of past singing experiences ranging from "not" to "a lot," presenting today with chief complaint of wanting to rock out. Symptoms began in 2005 when UMMS was noted to be A Cappella-deficient. The group went into remission in 2007, but returned in 2009. From 2020-21, the group members found themselves occasionally hearing voices and singing to themselves alone in their bedrooms. A brisk resuscitation began in fall of 2021 although the group made an even stronger comeback in 2022.

Physical Exam:
General: appropriately fun-loving attitude with elevated energy level
CV: upbeat rate and rhythm
Lung: clear harmonies bilaterally

Assessment:
Ready to knock your socks off.

Plan:
1. Visit our Facebook page at http://tinyurl.com/umms-auscultations-fb

2. Sit back and enjoy.
Summary: The Auscultations is a co-ed a cappella group made up of University of Michigan Medical School students.  Students have tons of fun performing a cappella music for a variety of audiences, including patients at the hospital.

Name: The Aviation Club at Ross
Description: The club will accomplish three primary objectives. The first is to serve as an educational hub for people of all backgrounds (newcomers and industry veterans) to learn about the aviation industry. Second, the club will enhance the professional networks of Ross students in the growing industries of commercial and defense aviation and connect members with top-tier career opportunities in aviation. Finally, the club will develop a community of aviation enthusiasts at Ross by hosting professional and social events.
Summary: The mission of the Aviation Club at Ross is to raise awareness of the aviation industry, support the professional growth of students recruiting for the industry, and develop a community of aviation enthusiasts at Ross!

Name: The Classical Guitar Society at the University of Michigan
Description: The Classical Guitar Society at the University of Michigan is a group that aims to provide its members opportunities to meet, learn from, and collaborate with other classical and fingerstyle guitarists in a fun, low-stakes setting.
Summary: The Classical Guitar Society at the University of Michigan is a group that aims to provide its members opportunities to meet, learn from, and collaborate with other classical and fingerstyle guitarists in a fun, low-stakes setting.

Name: The Compulsive Lyres
Description:
The Compulsive Lyres is a tight-knit group of upbeat students dedicated to performing and arranging A Cappella music from a variety of different genres. The Lyres host a concert each semester, perform at both on-campus and off-campus gigs, and attend a retreat every semester which never fails to bring us closer as a group. The Lyres are comprised of charismatic, motivated, sarcastic, creative, devoted individuals who take pride in the music that we create and the family that we have become. Make sure to check out our recent EP and newest single on Spotify or Apple Music, and to follow us on Instagram @thecompulsivelyres for more information! Please enjoy this video of the Lyres' performance at the 2023 ICCA Great Lakes Quarterfinals:

https://youtu.be/imu_hczM-X4
Summary: The Lyres are an a cappella group that performs and arranges songs from a variety of genres- everything from Miley Cyrus to Stevie Wonder! We perform at a variety of gigs, host a concert each semester, and are best known for winning ICCA in 2002.

Name: The Creator Society
Description: The Michigan Creator Society is a dynamic community of self-starters, entrepreneurs, and visionaries. Through weekly outings like nature walks, fireside chats, hikes, and campus strolls, we go beyond traditional networking events. We are a close-knit family of creators who thrive on learning through hands-on experiences and adventures. Our focus is to embrace new experiences that conjoin diverse individuals, which foster a rich tapestry of perspectives and ideas. Join us to inspire, fuel motivation, and spark discovery within a supportive and authentic community. We welcome those who are boldly pursuing their dreams—everyone who identifies as a creator is invited.
Summary: The Creator Society at Michigan is a place to connect with self-starters, entrepreneurs, and visionaries who are boldly pursuing their dreams—everyone who identifies as a creator is invited.

Name: The Dance Student Assembly
Description:
MISSION STATEMENT

The Dance Student Assembly (DSA) is committed to a nourishing and supportive learning environment by representing undergraduate and graduate students' learning interests, concerns, and issues relating to policies in the Department of Dance. DSA comprises one volunteer representative from each of the undergraduate and graduate classes, in addition to the President and Vice President. Members report to and collaborate with the Chair of the Department on a regular basis allowing for DSA to act as both a formal and informal liaison between students and the faculty. Moreover, DSA organizes student activities, keeps them informed of events occurring in the Department, provides an open forum for students to voice their opinions and always strives to collaborate with other Departments in the School of Music, Theatre & Dance. DSA strongly encourages active participation in Department activities led by students, faculty and guests.
Summary: The Dance Student Assembly is the official student government of the Dance Department at the University of Michigan.

Name: The Detroit Partnership
Description: The DP exists in order to facilitate service-learning opportunities for volunteers in the city of Detroit. This organization is an initiative to involve a diverse student population in service, and to create sustainable partnerships between students and community groups. The DP is a resource available to the University of Michigan and greater community for active service-learning opportunities. In addition to weekly programs, the organization also holds two large events. In the fall, The Detroit Partnership partners with community members to bring a large food and clothing drive titled One-Stop Shop to the citizens of Brightmoore and surrounding areas. Also, every March or April the group routinely brings 300+ volunteers to sites across Detroit for a one-day service-learning event known as DP Day.
Summary: The Detroit Partnership seeks to connect the students at the University of Michigan with Detroit-based community partners by facilitating service-learning opportunities and on-campus events.

Name: The DR's Laboratory
Description: The DR’s Laboratory finds new territory for Black artists on and behind the stage and screen by innovating equitable processes and protocols that inform our development of authentic, Black productions. We advance Black liberation research to divest from prejudices within performance, discover new solutions to exploitation in entertainment, and develop new forms in film and fine arts.
Summary: The DR's Laboratory is a process-production company finding new territory for Black artists in film and fine arts through research and storytelling.

Name: The Evergarden
Description:
The Evergarden dedicates itself to its three pillars: Gardening Initiatives, Cultural Botany, and Green Advocacy.

It will be The Evergarden’s main goal to engage, educate, enrich, and advocate for the local community!
Summary: Anyone can garden!

Name: The Federalist Society at the University of Michigan Law School
Description: The Federalist Society at the University of Michigan is a non-profit membership organization dedicated to bringing conservative and libertarian ideas into legal education. We sponsor debates, speeches and symposia to advance our principles that the state exists to preserve freedom, that the separation of governmental powers is central to our Constitution and that it is emphatically the province and duty of the judiciary to say what the law is, not what it should be.
Summary: The Federalist Society is a non-profit membership organization dedicated to supplying conservative and libertarian ideas in legal education and discourse. We sponsor debates and speeches that are open to all who are interested.

Name: The Friars
Description: An a cappella subset of the University of Michigan Men's Glee Club (UMMGC), consisting of 9 members. The Friars travel with UMMGC on tours and other club functions.
Summary: 9 men, 4 voice parts, and plenty of awful dance moves. The Friars have been 'entertaining' audiences for over 50 years, and are proud members of the University of Michigan Men's Glee Club.

Name: The Gaia Project at Michigan
Description: The Gaia Project at Michigan is an independent non-profit group that campaigns for environmental protection and gender equity by advocating real-world solutions to sustainability, equity, and equality.
Summary: We, the Gaia Project at Michigan, in order to advocate for environmental protection and gender equity, do hereby establish this constitution.

Name: The Gentlemen
Description: The goal of The G-Men (Gentlemen for long) is to perform a cappella music while having a good time. We perform all types of music and are open to any sort of music opportunities, including recording albums, competing on the national stage, and touring the county. We rehearse 3 times a week and regularly hold concerts and gig around the community. Every spring break, we embark on a weeklong tour and we occasionally travel for gigs. More information about our group and the audition process can be found at our website, thegmen.org. We welcome all singers regardless of previous music experience!
Summary: The G-Men (or Gentlemen for long) is the premier all-male a cappella group at Michigan. The group strives to create unique music while having a good time. In recent years, The G-Men have toured the country, performed in the community, and placed in ICCA.

Name: The Ginsberg Center for Community Service Learning
Description: Through service, community partnerships and social justice education, the Ginsberg Center enriches student learning, advances community priorities and inspires a lifelong commitment to citizenship. The Ginsberg Center offers a range of programs and works with students and faculty to strengthen community service learning across the University of Michigan.
Summary: The Ginsberg Center’s mission is to engage students, faculty and community members in learning together through community service and civic engagement in a diverse, democratic society.

Name: The Gourmet Club
Description: The purpose of the Gourmet Club is to unite Ross's foodies of all levels and provide a fun community to converse and form friendships over food. We are also a place where students of diverse backgrounds can learn to cook intricate meals from student-led cooking demos. Our events focus on bringing together smaller groups of people to learn about each other in intimate settings at restaurants, cafes, farms, and dinner parties from Ann Arbor to Detroit. Most importantly, we are a club where if you have any passion for how the power of food can connect us all, the Gourmet Club is the place to be.
Summary: The purpose of the Gourmet Club is to unite Ross's foodies of all levels and provide a fun community to converse and form friendships over food.

Name: The Great UofM Baking Club
Description:
We're a haven for baking enthusiasts at the University of Michigan!

Our mission is to:
• Empower budding bakers to hone their craft.
• Offer a therapeutic baking escape to bust student stress.
• Create a warm community where bakers connect and collaborate. Whether you're a seasoned baker or just starting your sweet journey, you're in the right place!

Our Activities 
• Baking Lessons: Dive deeper into the world of baking through hands-on experience making classics like macarons or bread.
• Baking Competitions: Teams whip up delights themed to the competition. With multiple teams, it's a race to impress the judges.
• Baking Potlucks: Imagine competitions, but more relaxed. Everyone brings something to the table, quite literally, making it a treat-filled gathering.
• Baking Fundraisers: Showcase your baking skills and contribute to a cause. Whether it's for the club or charity, our campus bake sales are always a hit!
• Social Hangouts: From karaoke and bowling to painting the rock or exploring Ann Arbor's best bakeries, we make sure fun is always on the menu.

Join us, and let's create, collaborate, and celebrate the joy of baking together!

Check out our social media and more: https://linktr.ee/greatuofmbakingclub
Summary: The Great UofM Baking Club is an open, free community dedicated to making baking accessible and the perfect place for students of all baking levels to relieve stress and make friends!

Name: The Harmonettes
Description: Founded in 1979, the Harmonettes have been contributing to the ever-growing University of Michigan A Cappella community with their unique sound and signature blend. As the first A Cappella group on campus consisting of women and non-conforming individuals, these passionate musicians pride themselves on their inclusivity, tight-knit friendships, and innovative music. The Harmonettes, compassionately known as the Harmas, strive to create a community of laughter, support, and collaboration. Outside of rehearsals in the Bell Tower, they can be found studying late at the Union, learning music at retreats every semester, immersing themselves in numerous campus activities, and bonding over their love for Skylar Astin.
Summary: treble a cappella group

Name: The Health Equity Scholars Program
Description:
The Health Equity Scholars Program is a student driven initiative to create opportunities to learn about and participate in health equity work through reflections on service-learning, seminar discussions and an immersion experience in Detroit. This will encompass participation in monthly seminars investigating the multi-factorial reality of poverty, observation and evaluation of successful community programs, and service experiences at multiple locations in the Southeastern Michigan. Students who are accepted into this program will be required to participate in community service experiences of their choosing, which we will then reflect upon as a group. Allowing students to choose their own experiences will allow for greater commitment on the individual student’s part, as well as greater breadth of discussion.

Small discussion-based seminars will be scheduled monthly.  They are designed to supplement the service work, avoiding theory and abstraction, and focusing rather on the grounded, tangible knowledge and experiences of students and visiting speakers. For these seminar discussions a meal will be provided to be shared with the guest expert in an effort to encourage a discussion style format where the participants will be better able to ask questions and engage in the exchange of information.

HESP will also complete site visits to community-engaged organizations such as FQHCs and other community organizing centers. 

Site-visits are essential for our members to gain exposure to successful organizations that are working towards improving health equity. Survey data from previous years shows site visits to be one of the most impactful aspects of HESP. Site-visits also facilitate networking and mentorship between students and administrators at the facilities. Such relationships have developed into research projects and independent site-visits from HESP members. 

Finally, student members will participate in volunteerism through their own efforts or through the medical school's existing programs.
Summary: The Health Equity Scholars Program is a student driven initiative to create opportunities for medical students to learn about and participate in health equity work through reflections on service-learning, seminar discussions and volunteerism.

Name: The Impro-Fessionals
Description: We're the Impro-fessionals, the most unhinged improv comedy performance group on campus.(and the #1 collection of clowns). We perform free monthly shows for the student body that are full of HILARIOUS JOKES. Open auditions are held at the beginning of each semester. Check out our Instagram for more updates!
Summary: A short-form improvisational comedy group.

Name: The Juno Collective
Description:
Juno is established in order to address the need for a low-income, creative space on campus. Oftentimes in the hyper-academic, hyper-competitive environment of the University of Michigan experimentation that does not lead to an immediate profit, intellectual or economic, is disregarded. Similarly, despite the wealth of resources advertised by the University, all tend to be limited in some capacity, whether that be hidden Canvas courses, select majors, or few operating hours. Juno will seek a refugee from both of these issues, promoting artist experimentation and resource sharing.

In pursuit of these goals Juno will operate on three primary projects:

  1. The Juno website, which will be maintained and consistently updated with submissions of active and inactive members of the club.
  2. Juno events, facilitated by executive club officers.  This expands beyond club meetings and will include workshops, open mics, poetry readings, and art exhibitions.
  3. Juno “Projects”. These will be members and officers proposed but facilitated by executive club officers.
Summary: We are Juno, an art collective in Ann Arbor, MI. we formed to address the need for artist-focused spaces on campus, especially for lower-income creators. We are founded on expression, movement, work, and action above all.

Name: The Law School Classical Music Society
Description: The Law School Classical Music Society serves as both a music appreciation and a music performance society that functions a little like a symphony board. We are committed to hosting recitals by law school student body musicians. The Society provide resources for students to want to play music, who want to attend classical concerts with friends, and/or who want behind-the-scenes experience organizing recitals.
Summary: CMS is a law school student group whose goal is to promote an awareness of classical music and to provide a community for musicians and classical music enthusiasts. We are committed to hosting recitals by law school student body musicians.

Name: The Michigan Animation Club
Description:
The Michigan Animation Club (MAC) is dedicated to creating and appreciating animation. Our mission is to provide a safe and fun environment for students across all disciplines and experience levels to: access animation learning resources and information about the industry, explore both individual and collaborative projects, and watch/discuss animation with people who share their love for it. MAC also hosts speaker events with animation professionals, and other events like field trips and collaborations with other orgs! MAC events are dedicated to supporting the animation community at the University of Michigan and/or allowing members to have fun and build connections.

 

We meet in-person on Fridays, 6-8PM in Design Lab 1 (Room 1321) of the Duderstadt Center on North Campus. If remote, our meetings take place same day and time on our Discord server. Optional animation screenings follow until 9PM!

 

We do not have club dues or an application. To receive meeting info, club + animation announcements, opps, and resources, join our email list here (click "Join Group") and our Discord (we recommend joining both). Also, please connect with us on Instagram ! For any questions or concerns, please contact the current standing President at the email below!
Summary: The Michigan Animation Club is dedicated to creating and appreciating animation. We invite students from any year, department, or experience levels to join, the only specification being a passion to learn and create.

Name: The Michigan Archive
Description:
At the Archive, we want to provide a chance for non-history majors and history majors alike to write about, read about, and generally enjoy history and its documentation. This magazine is a chance to engage in historical writing, journalism, and all other artistic endeavors under the sun.

The Archive is open to all interested participants, no history background necessary.
Summary: The Archive serves to produce a student-written, edited, and designed magazine containing historical articles, essays, and art created by members and guest writers/artists.

Name: The Michigan Blacksmithing Club
Description: The Michigan Blacksmithing Club teaches members blacksmithing basics with various projects and also collaborates to design and forge a blade to showcase in the TMS Bladesmithing Competition. This event is designed to promote engagement within the field of materials science and provide students with opportunities for industry jobs and advanced research. Members play a part in fabricating the blade using traditional and modern bladesmithing methods, and perform material analysis using tools in the MSE Van Vlack Laboratory. In the off-season, members work on refining their own smithing skills to create blades for club use. No prior experience is necessary as members are all taught safety guidelines and basic hand forging skills at the beginning of each year. We encourage both engineering and non-engineering members to join and take a swing at some hot steel!
Summary: The Michigan Blacksmithing Club teaches members blacksmithing basics with various projects and also collaborates to design and forge a blade to showcase in the TMS Bladesmithing Competition.

Name: The Michigan Euchre Club
Description: The purpose of The Michigan Euchre Club is to develop student's euchre skills as well as provide them with an opportunity to play and compete with others.
Summary: The purpose of The Michigan Euchre Club is to develop student's euchre skills as well as provide them with an opportunity to play and compete with others.

Name: The Michigan Gayly: LGBTQ+ Issues
Description: The Michigan Gayly: LGBTQ+ Issues is a monthly periodical consisting of articles focused on LGBTQ+ issues here on campus and in the world at large. We want to elevate the voices of queer people in general with a focus on those who are most marginalized-- queer people of color, queer people of faith, trans and nonbinary folks, etc. We hope to create an outlet of self-expression for Michigan students of all backgrounds within the LGBTQ+ community, while also spreading awareness of LGBTQ+ issues to queer and straight readers alike.
Summary: The Michigan Gayly: LGBTQ+ Issues is a monthly periodical consisting of articles focused on LGBTQ+ issues here on campus and in the world at large.

Name: The Michigan Institute for Progressive Policy
Description: We are a student-run organization that seeks to research, write, and advocate for progressive policies. Regardless of your major or year, we would love to have you in our organization. We do not have dues or an application.
Summary: The purpose of MIPP is to bring student-initiated progressive public policy ideas into the public discourse and build skills and networks to make us more effective change agents of society upon leaving the university.

Name: The Michigan Law Review
Description: The Michigan Law Review (MLR) is a student-run legal journal that publishes eight issues per year. MLR publishes articles, online essays, book reviews, and student-written notes.
Summary: The Michigan Law Review (MLR) is a student-run legal journal that publishes eight issues per year. MLR publishes articles, online essays, book reviews, and student-written notes.

Name: The Michigan Quadball Team
Description:
We play Quadball, a full contact and all genders inclusive sport, using the rules provided by United States Quadball (USQ) against teams at other universities. Quadball is a fast paced, high intensity sport with a unique style of gameplay akin to a combination of basketball/rugby/dodgeball (for videos of gameplay check out our YouTube channel!). In the fall, we have practices throughout the week and attend around 4 tournaments at other universities over various weekends. In the winter, we have workout groups, a practice on the weekends, and usually attend 2-3 tournaments.

We are a social club as well and host regular game/movie nights, parties, and other team hangouts. If you want to be part of the MQ community but are not interested in athletics, we happily welcome anyone onto our Support Staff! Support Staff members are an invaluable part of our team who support us logistically at tournaments in addition to being social members of MQ. 

If you have any questions or are interested in joining the team, please reach out to us at michiganquidditch@gmail.com!
Summary: The Michigan Quadball Team (MQ) is an official member of United States Quadball, which adapted the sport from the Harry Potter books.

Name: The Muslim Coalition
Description: The Muslim Coalition is a union of Muslim-adjacent student organizations and groups at the University of Michigan. It aims to serve U-M's diverse Muslim student body and represent Muslim interests to the greater campus community in a pluralistic fashion. The Muslim Coalition shall have a Council, with delegates from the Muslim-adjacent student organizations at U-M and shall provide them with a forum to foster efficient communication, discussion, and collaboration. The Coalition shall facilitate and support Muslim-relevant projects that aim to address matters affecting all Muslim students on campus, such as access to prayer spaces, availability of bidets, surveying, and Ramadan programming. With these goals, the Coalition seeks to embrace U-M's diverse Muslim student community and enrich the Michigan experience.
Summary: The Muslim Coalition is a union of Muslim-affiliated student organizations at the University of Michigan. It aims to serve U-M's diverse Muslim student body and represent Muslim interests to the greater campus community.

Name: The National Society of Black Women in Medicine
Description: The National Society of Black Women in Medicine aims to increase the retention of underrepresented minority women pursuing careers in all pre-professional healthcare pathways.
Summary: The National Society of Black Women in Medicine aims to increase the retention of underrepresented minority women pursuing careers in all pre-professional healthcare pathways.

Name: The Neuroscience Student Association
Description:
The mission of this organization is to benefit students with an interest in neuroscience in their current roles as undergraduate students and in their future professions in a wide variety of fields by providing networking opportunities, seminars, and exposure to the depth of neuroscience.

We believe that neuroscience is fascinating, and that the field as a whole contains a wide array of opportunities that serve to reach advancements in applied science and health. Many students enter the University of Michigan with a limited understanding of available careers, and we hope to broaden their horizons by exposing them to medicine, public health, research, and engineering. Neuroscience is, at its very core, an interdisciplinary subject. It requires a relatively deep understanding of biology, chemistry, physics, and psychology. Beyond that, when it is crossed with computer programming, electrical engineering, biomedical engineering, or animal studies, it gains an even broader scope of possibilities. We hope to expose students to the many facets of this broad, advancing field.

If you are interested in joining the mailing list so that you can stay up-to-date with events, please email Caroline (cgebczak@umich.edu) or Tanay (tanbhan@umich.edu).
Summary: An association of students interested in applications of the advancing field of neuroscience.

Name: The Office of Student Conflict Resolution
Description: The Office of Student Conflict Resolution promotes a safe and scholarly community in which students navigate conflict in a peaceful, socially just, and self-reflexive manner. OSCR offers a spectrum of conflict resolution pathways that are educationally focused, student-driven, community owned, and restorative in nature, which are adaptable to meet the needs of individuals experiencing conflict.
Summary: The Office of Student Conflict Resolution promotes a safe and scholarly community in which students navigate conflict in a peaceful, socially just, and self-reflexive manner.

Name: The Pakistani Student Association
Description:
The Pakistani Student Association (PSA) is a student-run organization at the University of Michigan – Ann Arbor that works to create a home away from home for Pakistani students in Ann Arbor, and helps promote Pakistani culture within the Michigan community.

Keeping its vision in mind, PSA holds numerous events throughout the academic year. Some of our staple events are cricket watch parties, Piston's game nights, mentorship/study tables, and our capstone cultural event, Michigan Mehndi. PSA also plays a role in the Center for South Asian Studies' Pakistan Conference, where guest speakers with expertise on Pakistani society, politics, and political economy from leading research universities around the country are invited to present and engage in discussion on the pertinent issues facing Pakistan today.

We encourage all those interested in learning about Pakistan, participating in a cultural event, or settling in and getting comfortable on campus to become a member of our community. We are sure you will enjoy our company. Go Blue and Pakistan Zindabad!
Summary: The Pakistani Student Association (PSA) is a student-run organization at the University of Michigan – Ann Arbor that works to promote Pakistani culture within the university community.

Name: The Pearl Project
Description: The Pearl Project’s mission is to assist young mothers in financially unstable circumstances by providing free childcare services and emotional strength to allow them to finish their education and acquire a stable career. To that end, The Pearl Project will support a free daycare, Roseland Community “Good News” Daycare, on the South Side of Chicago with fundraising events and volunteering at the daycare on an alternative spring break. Additionally, The Pearl Project will branch its efforts out to the surrounding South Side area and provide education on what it really means to volunteer by serving the Washtenaw County in Michigan.
Summary: The Pearl Project is an organization dedicated to supporting the Roseland "Good News" Daycare on the South Side of Chicago. Members will volunteer at the daycare as an alternative spring break and will gain the tools for thoughtful volunteering.

Name: The PhD Forum at the Stephen M. Ross School of Business
Description: The Forum is a student group whose primary purpose is addressing the needs of the Ross PhD student body. From social events to resources essential for a successful doctoral candidate in business, the Forum will provide supplemental services to ensure the success of doctoral students during their academic careers at Ross.
Summary: The PhD Forum is a student group open to any currently enrolled PhD student at the Ross School of Business at the University of Michigan.

Name: The Pickleball Club at Ross
Description: The Pickleball Club at Ross creates opportunities for Ross MBA students to play pickleball and connect through open play, tournaments, workshops, and social events.
Summary: The Pickleball Club at Ross creates opportunities for Ross MBA students to play pickleball and connect through open play, tournaments, workshops, and social events.

Name: The Pierpont Commons Board of Representatives
Description:
The Pierpont Commons Board of Representatives is to serve as a communications link between The Pierpont Commons and students, faculty, staff, and alumni; to represent and be accountable to these constituencies when developing The Pierpont Commons policies and to actively promote and develop the role of each constituency in the activities of The Pierpont Commons. 

Key Projects:

  • Opening of the North Campus Reflection Room
  • Artwork selections for building
  • Sustainability initiatives
  • North Campus student engagement
  • Partnerships across North Campus schools and colleges
  • Reservation and scheduling policy changes
  • Space utilization
  • Installation of Messages of Hope display
Summary: The Pierpont Commons Board of Representatives (PCBR) serves as an interdisciplinary advisory board to the Director of Pierpont Commons.  The PCBR strives to provide suggestions and put forth concerns of its constituencies.

Name: The Program on Intergroup Relations
Description: The Program on Intergroup Relations (IGR) is a social justice education program. We offer courses as well as co-curricular programming that blends theory and experiential learning to facilitate students' learning about social group identity, social inequality, and intergroup relations. The program prepares students to live and work in a diverse world and educates them in making choices that advance equity, justice, and peace. IGR is a partnership between Student Life and the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts.
Summary: The Program on Intergroup Relations (IGR) is a social justice education program. IGR blends theory and experiential learning to facilitate students' learning about social group identity, social inequality, and intergroup relations.

Name: The Quarterdeck Society
Description: The Quarterdeck Society is a student organization dedicated to serving the students of the Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering department. Quarterdeck provides to its members the ability to advance themselves professionally, gain a better awareness of our industry, and build a valuable network consisting of fellow students as well as industry professionals.  All of this is accomplished through corporate presentations, industry related field trips, attendance to the Great Lakes/Great Rivers SNAME section meetings and the SNAME Annual Meeting, volunteer opportunities, mentorship  and social events. Both undergraduate and graduate students welcomed!
Summary: The Quarterdeck Society aims to give its members a variety of opportunities ranging from professional development and networking opportunities to social events and mentorship in the Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering community.

Name: The Quito Project
Description:
The Quito Project is a multidisciplinary organization with students and faculty from schools across the University of Michigan including: Social Work, Nursing, Education, Business, Literature Sciences & Arts, Engineering, etc. As of 2023, TQP is in its nineteenth year of operation. Since its formation in 2004, TQP has evolved to support projects in the realm of public health, social work, and education for 8,000 community members of San Martin, San Blas, and Pifo in Quito, Ecuador.

The Quito Project’s mission is to collaborate with local partners in developing evidence-based solutions that support and build capacity in the health, educational, and social sectors.

 

TQP Model:  In partnership with the Universidad de San Francisco in Quito, students from the University of Michigan partner with education students in Ecuador to hold a summer camp for underprivileged children each summer. The curriculum is student-developed with support from mentor faculty members and emphasizes the strengthening students' understanding of public health and core academic subjects in reading, writing, mathematics and the sciences while encouraging creative expression and exploration, elevating the importance of academic performance, and boosting in-class self-confidence.  Each year approximately 60 students aged 5-12 years old attend the camp. 

We provide our students with engaging educational activities, two meals at the summer camp, school supplies, and hygienic supplies which is entirely free of charge and organized by undergraduate students from the University of Michigan and La Universidad San Francisco de Quito. 

 

Membership: The Quito Project members are recruited and managed by the TQP executive board and our faculty advisor. Every fall, TQP recruits UM undergraduate students through campus events, direct marketing, and social media campaigns. Prospective tutors for our program must complete an application and an interview conducted in both English and Spanish before being selected to participate in our summer travel program. However, traditional membership for on-campus activities throughout the school year is open to all and does not have an application nor interview.
Summary: The Quito Project is a multidisciplinary organization working to advance education alongside low-resource communities in Ecuador, organized by the collaborative efforts of students from the University of Michigan and La Universidad San Francisco de Quito

Name: The RC Review
Description:
The RC Review is the annually published literary magazine of the Residential College, a subdivision of UM's College of Literature, Science, and the Arts. Each year, we publish student poetry, prose, photography, art, and any other creative work that can fit flat on a page (or be uploaded on our website). We always welcome new staff members to take part in the process of reviewing submissions, assembling the magazine, advertising, fundraising, and other literary hijinks.

Find us at thercreview.com or @thercreview on Instagram.

To join our email list for meeting times and events, click HERE!
Summary: The annual literary magazine of the Residential College, publishing student poetry, prose, photography, art, and any other creative work that can fit flat on a page.

Name: The Red Glasses Movement at the University of Michigan
Summary: The goal of The Red Glasses Movement chapter at the University of Michigan is to the bridge the gap between between individuals with and without disabilities to allow ALL to feel included and loved through fundraising and volunteering.

Name: The Rho Chi Society Alpha Chapter
Description:
The Society's vision is to achieve universal recognition of its members as lifelong intellectual leaders in pharmacy. As a community of scholars, the Society will instill the desire to pursue intellectual excellence and critical inquiry to advance the profession.

The Mission of the Society is to encourage and recognize excellence in intellectual achievement and foster fellowship among its members. Further, the Society encourages high standards of conduct and character and advocates critical inquiry in all aspects of pharmacy.
Summary: To advance practice and pharmaceutical sciences through the encouragement and recognition of sound scholarship

Name: The Serotonin Society
Description: The Serotonin Society aims to create a supportive community for pre-health students by promoting mental wellness and self-care practices. We believe that maintaining good mental health is essential for academic success and professional growth. Through a variety of activities, such as workshops, discussions, and social events, we strive to raise awareness about mental health issues and combat the stigma associated with seeking help. Our ultimate goal is to empower pre-health students to prioritize their mental health and build resilience for the challenges ahead.
Summary: The Serotonin Society is established for students with pre-health concentrations who value mental and physical health and wellness, as well as pre-health students looking to connect with their peers outside of an academic setting.

Name: The Sirens A Cappella
Description: The Sirens are an all female a cappella group at the University of Michigan dedicated to their legacy of musical excellence, female empowerment, and creative expression. Formed in 2011, the Sirens are committed to fostering an inclusive environment for all members, exploring and challenging their vocal abilities, and supporting each other as the Leaders and Best!
Summary: The Sirens is an all-female a cappella group, dedicated to musical excellence, maintaining democracy, and building friendships. Through our performances, values, and community, we create a positive, fun, unique, and artistic presence on campus.

Name: The Smile Bringer Singers
Description:
The group was started by alumnus Sasha Altschuler in 2010. Since its creation, the group has grown to become well-known not only in the University of Michigan community, but in the Ann Arbor and surrounding area as well. 

We are a group of upbeat University of Michigan students dedicated to making a positive difference in our community! We perform at Nursing Homes, Assisted Living Facilities, a girls group home, as well as at different events on campus. And we are always looking for new places to attend.

We sing energetic songs- both old and new- such as "Build Me Up Buttercup," "Shake It Off," and "Footloose," making each one special and made just for you!

The Smile Bringer Singers is a unique, innovative group of students with compassion, talent, and committment to spreading happiness through harmonies!
Summary: The Smile Bringer Singers is a group designed to bring happiness and inspiration to our surrounding areas. We mix our passions for performing and community service to create a positive, fun, and loving organization.

Name: The Sopranos
Description: The Sopranos is a treble a cappella group dedicated to singing and performing together. We perform in numerous campus events throughout the year, as well as present one concert per semester. Our goal is to entertain the community while enjoying the sense of camaraderie that comes from being a part of a University organization. We pride ourselves on being a diverse and open group of women who love to laugh just as much as we love to sing.
Summary: The Sopranos is a treble a cappella group dedicated to singing and performing together. We perform in numerous campus events throughout the year, as well as present one concert per semester.

Name: The Squirrel Club
Description: The Squirrel Club is an organization of students, alumni, and members of the community that come together every Sunday during the fall and winter semesters to feed squirrels. Anyone is welcome to come to a meeting regardless of whether they are signed up for the club or not. Proceeds from t-shirt sales go to purchasing peanuts that are passed out at meetings (mainly to be fed to the squirrels). The technique that has been perfected is demonstrated and taught at meetings for those who are new, and results in an enjoyable outdoor experience that is unique to the University of Michigan.
Summary: The Squirrel Club is a fun and easy student organization that meets approximately every Sunday during the school year to feed squirrels in the Diag and around campus. Anyone and everyone is welcome to join!

Name: The SunBundle
Description: The SunBundle is a non-profit organization dedicated to providing diverse hands-on opportunities to support and raise funds for the well-being of others. Our vision is to promote wellness by utilizing funds for the creation and distribution of care-packages to individuals in underprivileged areas. We want to cultivate an environment of people who want to make a difference, and transform the way that health&wellness are viewed around the world!
Summary: A non-profit organization dedicated to helping individuals jumpstart their wellness journeys.

Name: The Thomistic Institute at the University of Michigan
Description: The mission of the Thomistic Institute at the University of Michigan is to promote academic discussion of the Catholic church’s intellectual tradition, placing particular emphasis on the thought of the 13th-century philosopher and theologian, Thomas Aquinas. The Thomistic Institute at the University of Michigan invites scholars from other academic institutions to the University of Michigan’s campus for lectures on philosophical and theological topics. The audience for these lectures includes any University of Michigan student or faculty with interest in the above. The Thomistic Institute at the University of Michigan also organizes other academic events pursuant to its mission such as reading and study groups.
Summary: The mission of the Thomistic Institute at the University of Michigan is to promote academic discussion of the Catholic church’s intellectual tradition by inviting scholars from other academic institutions for lectures and by leading small groups.

Name: The Undergraduate Journal of Public Health
Description:
The Undergraduate Journal of Public Health is established with the purpose of increasing awareness of local, national, and international public health related issues within the the University of Michigan campus and the greater Ann Arbor community.

We aim to to create a platform for students to voice their opinions and engage with peers on a variety of public health issues and topics. This will be accomplished through the release of an annual printed journal as well as rolling blog articles.
Summary: Our mission is to provide a platform for undergraduate students at UMich and other universities to publish articles on public health topics such as healthcare access, health disparities, social justice, and epidemiology.

Name: The University of Michigan College of Engineering Honor Council
Description:
The Engineering Honor Council is a distinguished student-led organization that has been serving the College of Engineering for over a century. Our mandate is to ensure the administration of the Honor Code is conducted in a fair and impartial manner. We are responsible for investigating reported violations, providing education to students and faculty regarding the Honor Code, and ensuring that all parties involved in the process are treated with the utmost respect and fairness. To achieve this, we recruit investigators and faculty representatives from various departments within the college, to ensure that each case is examined from a comprehensive and holistic perspective. We are committed to maintaining the highest standards of integrity and accountability within the College of Engineering.

 

If you would like to apply to our organization we are actively recruiting engineering first and second-year undergrad and Ph.D. students year-round: http://bitly.ws/tYAb
Summary: Founded in 1906 by Michigan undergraduates, we aim to uphold the Engineering Honor Code, promote student integrity, and work with students and faculty to reduce academic violations on campus.

Name: The University of Michigan Czech Student Association
Description:
The University of Michigan Czech Student Association is a student-run organization that focuses on building a stronger Czech community among the student body. This club will provide a space for students of Czech heritage, as well as students interested in the Czech to learn more about Czech culture through cultural events, as well as a long-term oral history project highlighting the Czech and Czech American community. 

If you are interested in joining or learning more about the University of Michigan Czech Student Association, please email us at timcheek@umich.edu! We would love to meet you!
Summary: The University of Michigan Czech Student Association is a student-run organization that focuses on building a stronger Czech community among the student body.

Name: The University of Michigan Fencing Club
Description:
The University of Michigan Fencing Club is a competitive training environment for experienced fencers and newcomers alike. We offer an inclusive atmosphere that encourages fencers to improve to the best of their abilities while developing supportive relationships with their teammates. 

To join our practices, you will need the Participation Agreement filled out and approved. The agreement is under the Forms section. Practices are Monday, Wednesdays, and Friday at the Sports Coliseum 7pm-9pm.
Summary: The University of Michigan Fencing Club provides opportunities for both experienced fencers and newcomers to train and compete at the collegiate level. We are open to all students, staff, and faculty at the University of Michigan.

Name: The University of Michigan Polish Student Association
Description:
The University of Michigan Polish Student Association is a student run organization with the purpose of spreading Polish culture on campus and to the surrounding areas of Ann Arbor. We bring together Polish students, citizens and their friends by organizing a wide variety of social and cultural events throughout the year, including several mixers and bonfires, which allow for our members and friends to interact. Students experience Polish culture by participating in the special events we hold such as Andrejki (St. Andrews Day) and Pisanki (Easter Egg Decorating). They are also more than welcome to come cook Polish favorites, Pierogi and Golapki, at any one of our cooking events during the year.

Aside from all the events hosted by the organization, we work closely with our friends from the Polish American Congress and the Political Cultural Fund in assisting them with the preparation of the Annual Ann Arbor Polish Film festival. We have strong ties with the Copernicus Program in Polish Studies and the Department of Slavic Languages and Literatures and help them accommodate visitors invited from Poland and neighboring Slavic countries. 

We plan on hosting many more events this year and welcome everyone to come join us at any one of them to socialize and learn about our culture.
Summary: The University of Michigan Polish Student Association is a student run organization with the purpose of spreading Polish culture on campus and to the surrounding areas of Ann Arbor.

Name: The Urban Planning Student Association
Description: UPSA explores, promotes, and supports academic understanding, professional development, and the overall advancement of the field of Urban and Regional Planning.  To uphold these objectives, UPSA provides a forum for intellectual and social interaction among students of Urban Planning, promotes fellowship between Urban Planning students and the faculty/staff within the Department of Urban and Regional Planning, acts as the official spokesperson for the Masters students within the Department, and promotes interest in and understanding of the Urban Planning profession.
Summary: To explore, promote and support academic understanding, professional development, and the overall advancement of the field of Urban & Regional Planning.

Name: The Urban Wordsmith Society
Description: It is our mission and obligation to promote and foster artistic freedom and philanthropic ideas in minority communities and urban environments that promote unity, writing, and creative expression. Collectively, we will constitute a voice for people coming from marginalized communities that will strive to familiarize others with the struggles of underrepresented Americans. Our fundamental purpose will follow an original 4-block commandment represented by the acronym MAAP (Minority based, Activism, Art, & Philanthropy). This constitutes our goal to strive to respectfully represent minorities through activism, art, and philanthropy. MAAP is a guide for U.W.S. and will play a key role in our fundamental decision-making as an organization. At U.W.S. we will provide a safe and familiar environment for all P.O.C, where each member can hone their skills and participate in movements or shows meant to give back to our communities through entertainment and any aid we find ourselves capable of.
Summary: The Urban Wordsmith Society is an organization designed to foster artistic expression in minority communities through conversations, literature, and creative auditory expression. All voices are welcome and anyone is welcome to come share and listen.

Name: The Wellness Project
Description: The Wellness Project aims to help educate the younger generation on concepts of health and wellness focusing on Whole Health and Integrative Medicine by school and community interventions. The interventions will include educating younger students how to care for their own health through activities es and lessons based on the circle of Whole Health.
Summary: The Wellness Project aims to help educate the younger generation on concepts of health and wellness focusing on Whole Health and Integrative Medicine by school and community interventions.

Name: The Women's Network at Michigan
Description:
TWN is the largest collegiate women’s networking organization in the United States. Through personal, professional, and career development opportunities, TWN seeks to connect ambitious, high-achieving women and non-binary folks to each other and industry leaders. There are currently 45,000+ TWN members spanning 120 chapters on college campuses in the United States and Canada.

A women-led networking community. Connecting college students to professional leaders. Redefining ambition. Preparing future leaders

Nationals Webpage: https://www.thewomens.network/

Join the network!  https://www.thewomens.network/jointwn
Summary: A women-led networking community. Connecting college students to professional leaders. Redefining ambition. Preparing future leaders

Name: The Youth Movement Against Alzheimer's
Description: YMAA is a non-profit student organization aimed at promoting the understanding of Alzheimer’s among the youth by providing opportunities to help those affected by this disease through research, advocacy, and volunteerism. Our vision is to create a culture where our youth embrace aging and help alleviate the impact of Alzheimer’s Disease.
Summary: YMAA is a non-profit student organization aimed at promoting the understanding of Alzheimer’s among the youth by providing opportunities to help those affected by this disease through research, advocacy, and volunteerism.

Name: Theta Alpha Psi
Description: Theta Alpha Psi’s leadership and members are committed to our values of activism, education, friendship, and community within our fraternity operations, initiatives, and interactions. Through academic, professional, and personal education Theta Alpha Psi will focus on three clusters of Business, Technology, and Environment regarding social and environmental sustainability to inform students passionate about these sectors. Theta Alpha Psi is committed to diversity, equity, inclusion, and justice within our recruitment, education, partnerships, and fundraising.
Summary: Theta Alpha Psi is a professional co-ed sustainability fraternity with the purpose to connect students passionate about environmental and social sustainability topics and educate undergraduates with accurate and inclusive sustainable-action knowledge.

Name: Theta Capital
Description:
Founded in 2019, Theta Capital is a highly selective public markets investing and trading organization at the University of Michigan Stephen M. Ross School of Business.

Theta Capital models itself after a multimanager investment fund, allowing new analysts to learn from experienced portfolio managers, who actively invest. Analysts are given the opportunity to take ownership of their ideas through investment recommendations and trade execution. Daily discussion in our stock market Discord channel is a key component of our investment & trading processes. 

Theta capital is unique in that we focus on a mix of long/short equity, bonds, and derivatives. We provide an experience similar to what it is like working at an investment fund.

There are also resources provided for members to go directly into buy-side investment positions out of undergrad.
Summary: Theta Capital is a University of Michigan equity research club centered around finding winning investments/trades and active market discussion.

Name: Theta Tau Professional Engineering Fraternity
Description:
Theta Tau is a brotherhood of engineers dedicated to bolstering our professional and social lives through professional development workshops such as resume builders and "career fair tips" presentations, many philanthropic opportunities with local charities such as Food Gatherers or DAPCEP, and social events that include a weekend retreat, semi-formal dinner, and a multitude of fun activities with our brothers.

 

Interested in rushing? please don't join our maize pages roster - instead follow our Instagram account @thetatau_umich for rush information, hope to see you soon :)
Summary: Theta Tau is a co-ed professional engineering fraternity that combines the best aspects of social life and professionalism to create a close knit brotherhood.

Name: Theta Xi Fraternity, Sigma Chapter
Description:
The Sigma Chapter of Theta Xi was brought to the University of Michigan on April 10, 1914 and has demonstrated its illustrious presence on campus ever since. Within this house lie rich traditions, good values, community, and a long lasting brotherhood one can't find anywhere else.

We strive to promote goodness and instill core values within our members so that, upon completion of our undergraduate careers, we go out into the world as respected, and honorable men. Consider membership an enriching experience that will help you grow into the person you set out to be.
Summary: Theta Xi Fraternity is a national leader in the educational and social development of its members. Our successes and diversity have been celebrated by over 60,000 members since 1864.

Name: Thus Spoke Ann Arbor
Description: A Chinese drama club focusing on performing modern Chinese dramas. We are a group of people who are passionate about learning and practicing performing skills and scriptwriting. Our primary goal is to promote communications among different cultures and especially to introduce an important part of chinese culture. The main activities of the club include basic performing skill learning and acting, and making a play or acting a existing play by students ourselves. We are going to hold a drama concert every semester. We welcome people from all levels of performing to learn and enjoy, and people who have special skills to express their talents.
Summary: A Chinese drama club focusing on performing modern Chinese dramas. We are a group of people who are passionate about learning and practicing performing skills and scriptwriting, as well as promoting communications among different cultures.

Name: TJ Hooper & the Learned Hands
Description: TJ Hooper & the Learned Hands is a musical ensemble made up of law school students. The group's mission is to provide entertainment to the law school student body and musical opportunities for its members through performances at school events. The group has traditionally been a rock/pop ensemble that performs cover versions of popular songs at school events such as the Halloween Party and Law Prom.
Summary: TJ Hooper & the Learned Hands is a musical ensemble of law school students. The group's mission is to provide entertainment to the law school student body and musical opportunities for its members through performances at school events.

Name: Touch of Blue: New American Vocal Ensemble
Description:
Touch of Blue (formerly known as BlueNote Vocal Ensemble) is comprised of musicians who have a strong desire to improve their overall musicianship through jazz and improvisational study and learn through peer-to-peer mentorship. As an extracurricular group, the ensemble will meet approximately 1-2 times a week with more rehearsal time pending on an upcoming performance. 
 
The group will work towards one main performance at the end of each semester, and will make guest appearances on other departmental concerts as well as participate in outreach events scattered throughout the year. Spring of 2023 will mark the beginning of an annual Vocal Jazz Competition hosted by Touch of Blue featuring other collegiate vocal jazz ensembles in the Midwest.
 
Touch of Blue's mission is to inspire diverse audiences through the exploration and presentation of jazz-centric American vocal music, with a commitment to uplifting and celebrating this music through both improvisatory and more conventional performance modes.
Summary: Our mission is to inspire diverse audiences through the exploration and presentation of jazz-centric American vocal music, with a commitment to uplifting and celebrating this music through both improvisatory and more conventional performance modes.

Name: Treasuring Christ Collegiate Ministry at the University of Michigan
Description: TCCM’s purpose is to mobilize students to seek the good of the campus and live on mission through tangibly serving the needs of others, building a passion for God’s Word, cultivating community, fostering a desire for evangelism and discipleship, training for Christian leadership, equipping students to understand the implication of faith for their work, and connecting students to the local church.
Summary: TCCM is a student organization that seeks to multiply disciples of Jesus Christ who will delight in, declare, and display the Gospel in all of life and for the good of the University of Michigan.

Name: Trial Advocacy Society
Description: The Trial Advocacy Society (TAS) is an organization that encourages Michigan Law students to learn trial advocacy skills and equip them to pursue careers as trial lawyers. TAS offers law students opportunities to meet practicing trial attorneys, attend speaker events focused on trial theory and evidence, and participate in student-taught workshops on trial skills. To give students an opportunity to use their skills in practice, TAS coordinates tryouts, practices, and travel logistics for the Michigan Law School Mock Trial Team -- a select group of students who compete against other law school mock trial teams at regional and national tournaments. By providing opportunities to learn, practice, and compete, TAS aims to help law students gain the skills and knowledge necessary to be effective trial-level litigators.
Summary: The Trial Advocacy Society (TAS) is an organization focused on encouraging law students to learn trial advocacy skills through training workshops, speaker events, and mock trial competitions.

Name: Trotter Multicultural Center
Description:
About Us

The Trotter Multicultural Center is a wonderful space that offers many great amenities and programs for the university community. Not only do we have two computer labs equiped with printers (MPrint: Trotter), but we also have ample study and recreation space. In addition to our main floor lounge, both upper two floors are equiped with cable television for your viewing pleasure.

Trotter also provides free reservable space for student organizations to hold events or meetings. We are located right on Washtenaw, just minutes from CC Little. 

Hours of Operation

We are open 7 days a week from 9 AM until 10 PM during the Fall and Winter semesters. Hours vary during the summer, but are generally 9 AM until 5 PM.
Summary: The Trotter Multicultural Center offers facilities and programs to provide a supportive environment in which all students can develop a better understanding and appreciation for the multicultural diversity represented at the University of Michigan.

Name: Turkish Student Association at the University of Michigan
Description: The Turkish Student Association (TSA) is a social, cultural, non-political, and non-religious organization dedicated to fostering unity within the Turkish community and celebrating Turkish culture on campus. The association welcomes and engages participants from all backgrounds who are interested in Turkish culture. TSA's mission extends beyond social and cultural activities; it also acts as a resource for prospective and current students, providing valuable insights into life at the University of Michigan and the Ann Arbor area. Throughout the semester, TSA organizes a wide array of events and gatherings that aim to strengthen connections within the broader Turkish community and to share the vibrant culture of Turkey with the wider campus community.
Summary: TSA aims to promote Turkish culture on campus by organizing various events and meetings. We also provide information to prospective and current students about the life in Ann Arbor. We are open to everyone who wants to celebrate the Turkish culture.

Name: Turn Up Turnout
Description: Turn Up Turnout (TUT) is an organization dedicated to increasing youth voter turnout in the United States, especially in midterm elections. Our efforts include voter registration, education, and turnout mobilization. Join us if you are passionate about promoting voting among your peers.
Summary: Turn Up Turnout (TUT) is an organization dedicated to increasing youth voter turnout in the United States, especially in midterm elections. TUT initiated the Big Ten Voting Challenge.

Name: Tutors for Refugee Education Equality
Description:
Tutors for Refugee Education Equality (TREE) is an organization founded and based in Ann Arbor, Michigan at the University of Michigan. Our members are undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Michigan. We provide free personalized tutoring (virtual) to refugee children/children of refugees aged kindergarten to 12th grade. We are in connection with several refugee assisting organizations across Michigan that pass along our info to anyone who may need it. 

 

The tutors in TREE are all volunteers. This is a great opportunity to receive consistent volunteer hours! We encourage volunteers to meet with their assigned student once a week for at least an hour. All accepted tutors fill out a form highlighting their subject and grade level strengths, and are matched with a student with the appropriate needs. Training and guiding educational materials will be provided for reference. Sorting out the time, duration, and other logistical information is left to the tutor to arrange with the student in a way that works with both of their schedules. 

 

This is a great opportunity for those looking for teaching experience, volunteer hours, and a way to make a positive impact in the world around them. Please submit the interest form if you’d like to become a tutor! We have rolling admissions.
Summary: Tutors for Refugee Education Equality (TREE) is an organization founded and based in Ann Arbor, Michigan at the University of Michigan. We provide free personalized tutoring to refugee children/children of refugees aged kindergarten to 12th grade.

Name: Tzu Ching
Description: Tzu Ching, or Tzu Chi Collegiate Association [TCCA] at UM, is a student-led and run student organization that focuses on empowering our world through community action and reflection. TCCA has its core focuses on international relief, medicine, education and culture.  We promote environmental protection and conservation to fundraising for natural disasters. TCCA works to improve the campus through efforts related with Tzu Chi, an international relief non-profit organization.
Summary: Tzu Ching, or Tzu Chi Collegiate Association at UM, is a student-led and run student organization that focuses on empowering our world through community action and reflection.

Name: U-M Transit Services
Description: Join the Team that MAKES BLUE GO!! U-M Transit has a staff of over 100 student and non-student bus drivers that help provide the daily bus service on our Ann Arbor campuses. U-M Transit is a friendly, fun, and supportive place to work. The work is rewarding, the flexibility is ideal, and the opportunities to earn your CDL and gain valuable work experience can help you make the most of your time here! Most importantly, we know school is your priority and we're ready to work with your busy schedule! Safety is our first priority, and it starts with training! All of our training is conducted one-on-one. You'll work with our experienced and dedicated student training staff to: *Get your Commercial Driver's License. *Learn how to safely and comfortably operate our buses. *Learn how to confidently and reliably drive our routes. We'll pay you to train and cover your testing fees. It's a challenging program, but we'll work with you every step of the way! Trainees earn $16/hr and move to $18/hr after completing training Applicants must be current U-M students with at least 3 semesters remaining. Apply Now: https://ltp.umich.edu/campus-transit/transit-careers/
Summary: Join the Team that MAKES BLUE GO!! U-M Transit has a staff of over 100 student and non-student bus drivers that help provide the daily bus service on our Ann Arbor campuses.

Name: Ulman Foundation Cancer to 5K
Description: Cancer to 5K is a national program created by The Ulman Foundation that provides cancer survivors with a 12-week training program to run or walk a goal 5K race. During this program, student volunteers meet with survivors twice a week to train together. The focus of the program is connecting cancer survivors and helping them regain strength and trust in their bodies after cancer.
Summary: Cancer to 5K is a training program for cancer survivors to run or walk a goal 5K race. Student volunteers meet with survivors twice a week to train together, helping survivors regain strength and trust in their bodies after cancer.

Name: UM::Autonomy
Description:
Interested in joining the team for 2023-2024? Fill out our interest form for information about our mass meeting and to sign up for coffee chats (free coffee!) with team officers: https://forms.gle/RQ4nmRfPdG1tcrpG8

We are an engineering team that designs, fabricates, and programs a robotic surface vessel that can navigate obstacles and perform tasks on the open water all on its own with no human interaction. Working year-round, the team competes internationally against other autonomous boats every March in RoboNation's RoboBoat Competition in Sarasota, Florida. Last season, we took home 6th out of 28 teams, and won two awards - but this year, we're chasing the top. 

 

Our team is multidisciplinary, and has no barrier to entry - we encourage students from all different schools and colleges within the university with only a persistent curiosity and good spirits required. The goal of the team is to create a functional, efficient vessel while seeking out opportunities for learning and growth every step of the way. Bringing up questions and proposing adjustments are encouraged, as they help make a more cohesive team and a better overall product.

 

The team is split up into five main subteams: Mechanical, Electrical, AI, Advanced Capabilities, and Business.

 

The mechanical team designs and fabricates a new boat for competition each year, employing naval architecture and marine engineering principles to create resilient, waterproof hulls that can cut smoothly through the water, and a deck and superstructure that can support and protect the electronics housed within the boat. In addition, they provide support for mounting sensors onboard and help facilitate the boat's testing in the water in the Marine Hydrodynamics Laboratory. Students majoring in ME, NAME, ISME, RE, and many others can find their interests here!

 

Our electrical team is responsible for all electronics onboard - they ensure that the boat has a reliable, safe electrical system capable of supporting the immense amount of software running on deck, which is crucial to our overall performance. Every year, they build a full computer capable of supporting our AI team's work, designing printed circuit boards (PCBs), and protecting everything in secure housing. Students majoring in Computer and Electrical Engineering, as well as those interested in integrated systems in general, are encouraged to join!

 

The AI team develops all of the boat's software, and consists of the bulk of our team - without them, our boat would simply be a sitting duck. Their team consists of multiple parts - Computer Vision, Task Planning, and Navigation/Controls. All of these make up a software pipeline that work in tandem to perceive tasks and obstacles, plan paths around or toward them, and navigate the boat according to that path. Computer Science and Robotics Engineering students, as well as anyone interested in programming, is encouraged to join!

 

The Advanced Capabilities team is an interdisciplinary unit that works closely with other subteams to develop task-specific hardware and software that can vary wildly with the changes in competition challenges every year.
